I am enclosing herewith Voucher No. 500-47, $631.51, in favor of J. W. Mould & Son, Ltd., Edmonton, for plumbing work done at the Edmonton Indian School.

This covers the installation of the plumbing material purchased from Crane Limited, Edmonton, on P.O. 18450, plus the purchase and installation of 24 oak closet tanks which had rotted out. As far as I can ascertain, this latter item was not authorized. However, I am satisfied that it was necessary and would recommend that payment be authorized.

NOV 24 1947
Ottawa, December 3, 1947.

Mr. E.A. Robertson, Indian Agent,
Winterburn, Alberta.

We have your letter of November 20th enclosing voucher No. 500-47 for plumbing work done at the Edmonton Residential School. We are returning the voucher as it should show the number of hours each of the four men worked and the rate per hour. The charge for labour appears high.

In any case, the labour amounted to approximately $360, and the voucher is for $631. In other words, additional equipment at an approximate cost of $271 was secured without any purchase order or authority from the Department.

It is simply impossible for us to consider the payment of accounts unless regulations are followed; otherwise we would be totally unable to control our expenditures. Both the Principal and yourself are no doubt aware of purchasing regulations and in future the Department must insist that these be carried out to the letter. Otherwise payment of the accounts will not be made. It is hoped that it will not be necessary to bring this matter to your attention again.

A copy of this letter is being sent to Regional Supervisor Gooderham.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Referring to your letter of Sept. 23rd, 1947, returning voucher No. 402-47, in favor of Saskatoon Welding Co., for $1223.94.

Detailed account from the Saskatoon Welding Co., and is now attached to voucher which is returned herewith. In regard to quotations from other firms, would say that these boilers were in such condition that the Inspector intended to condemn them until it was pointed out to him by one of his assistants that this action would mean closing the school as no new boilers of this kind are available at present. We could not find any other firm who would even consider looking over the job and it was only after a great deal of talking that we were able to persuade the Saskatoon Welding Co. to undertake the work. When the boilers were torn down they were found to be in even worse condition than was at first thought.

In regard to supervision of the work, I was at the school once while they were working at the job and once when they were finishing. The Boiler Inspectors were there four times to inspect the work being done and either Mr. Staley or Mr. Faunt were in the building all the time the work was being done and inspected it on numerous occasions.

(Signed) E.A. Robertson,
Indian Agent.
Terrace Building,
Edmonton, August 1, 1947.

Attention Rev. Staley, Principal.

Dear Sir:

Confirming our verbal report on the condition of your boilers, the following are the repairs necessary in order that the boilers may be operated for the coming heating season.

Boiler No. (A) 6894 requires the bottom 7\(\frac{1}{2}\)" of the water legs cut off and new plates and foundation ring welded in place. New washout openings and a new return connection will be necessary in replaced outer sheet. An additional row of stays will also be necessary.

Boiler No. (A) 6895. The water legs of this boiler are extensively and deeply pitted with the pitting still active. We would suggest that this boiler be treated with zinc, lime and graphite to arrest the pitting, and that a connection for the blow-down be provided just above the foundation ring.

The above repairs will enable the boilers to operate for the coming winter, but we strongly recommend that serious consideration be given to replacing these boilers during the Summer of 1948.

Yours very truly,

(Signed) R. Scott,
Asst. Chief Inspector of Boilers.

Indian Residential School,
Box 138,
Edmonton, Alberta.

September 13, 1947.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Referring to your letter of Nov. 25th, in regard to voucher No. 486-47, $859.00, in favor of Gemmell Electric, covering repairs to electric wiring at Edmonton School.

At the time your authority for this work was received, the Gemmell Electric were at the school doing other work for Mr. Staley and as it was desired to have the repairs made before the students returned if at all possible, and Mr. Allan was not in a position to start the work immediately, Mr. Staley had these people go ahead with the work.

I did not realize that it would mean securing additional authority and will see that no changes of this kind are made in future.

E. A. Robertson,
Indian Agent.
AIR MAIL

Ottawa, December 16, 1947.

Mr. E.A. Roberton, Indian Agent,
Winterburn, Alberta.

We have your letter of the 4th instant, explaining why Gemmell Electric were engaged to do the electric wiring at the Edmonton School.

The Department finds it necessary to return the account as the item of $450.25 will have to be itemized showing the number or persons employed, the time each was employed and the rate per hour for each.

We have not heard anything further from you regarding your voucher No. 483 issued in favour of Taylor Tile and Contracting Company. As a result, this voucher has not been paid.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Mastic Flooring - Edmonton Residential School.

Referring to your letter of Nov. 25th, re above.

On receipt of your letter I wired the Department requesting that payment of my voucher No. 488-47, Nov. 3rd, $757.00, be held up until further advised. Mr. Freeze has not yet shown up to make this inspection and Ottawa are asking me for further advice as to payment.

I think possibly your attention was called to these floors when you were at the school on Oct. 24th. They had not looked just right to me when I first saw them but as they were the first mastic floors I had ever seen, I thought possibly I could be wrong. I phoned the Manager of the Taylor Tile & Contracting Co., and told him that he would have to go out to the school and satisfy Mr. Staley that the floors were all they should be. Mr. Grover, the manager, went to the school and finding Mr. Staley absent, inspected the floors with Mr. Faunt and the Matron, and Mr. Faunt phoned me that they were satisfied that floors were O.K., and I as a consequence, vouchered the account Nov. 3rd. However, Mr. Staley was apparently not notified that Mr. Grover had been out.

Mr. Staley now feels that in view of the guarantee given as to workmanship and materials by the Taylor Tile & Contracting Co., in their tender for this work, that it would be in order to pay the account and if the floor does not stand up, to make them replace it later.

Will you please advise your wishes in the matter.

In memorandum dated August 26th, 1947, we requested authority of the Deputy Minister to incur an expenditure not exceeding $800.00 for very necessary repairs to the electric wiring at the Edmonton Indian Residential School which is a Government-owned building.

Mr. Jackson who was then Acting Deputy Minister gave his approval and we so advised the Indian Agent. He has submitted the attached accounts amounting to $859.50 and as an explanation of the increased expenditure he writes as follows:

In our first communication of August 26th to the Deputy Minister we stated that Colin Allan would be employed to do the electrical work as his name had been given to us in Indian Agent Robertson's letter. DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

In memorandum dated August 26th, 1947, we requested authority of the Deputy Minister to incur an expenditure not exceeding $800.00 for very necessary repairs to the electric wiring at the Edmonton Indian Residential School which is a Government-owned building.

Mr. Jackson who was then Acting Deputy Minister gave his approval and we so advised the Indian Agent. He has submitted the attached accounts amounting to $859.50 and as an explanation of the increased expenditure he writes as follows:

"In regard to the additional expenditure of $59.50, you will note from my letter of Aug. 16th, that Mr. Allan would not make any definite tender for the work as there was no way of telling exactly what repairs would be required until the work was in progress and the $800.00 was a very indefinite figure."

In our first communication of August 26th to the Deputy Minister we stated that Colin Allan would be employed to do the electrical work as his name had been given to us in Indian Agent Robertson's letter. However, Gemmell Electric were employed to do the work and in explanation of this change Indian Agent Robertson writes,

"At the time your authority for this work was received, the Gemmell Electric were at the school doing other work..."
for Mr. Staley and as it was desired to have the repairs made before the students returned if at all possible, and Mr. Allan was not in a position to start the work immediately, Mr. Staley had these people go ahead with the work."

Please issue purchase order so that the account may be paid. The coding is as follows: 516-753-10-691.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

I am enclosing herewith several letters from Mr. Staley, Principal of the Edmonton Residential School, requesting authority for painting, repairs etc., at the Edmonton School.

I have listed these requests in what I consider their order of importance.

During the past year it has been necessary for the school to re-open the 2 dormitories on the upper floor which had not been used for a number of years. These rooms badly need decorating and new floors as requested.

The sewing room and the north-east class room also are in need of re-decorating as nothing has been done to them for a number of years. The table and benches in the children's dining room are also in poor condition and I believe Miss McCready, the dietician, may also have recommended that they be replaced from a sanitary view point.

In regard to the potato peeling machine, this would appear to be a reasonable request as they have about an average of 175 to feed and peeling potatoes by hand for this number takes a lot of time which could be used to better advantage in other ways. The washing machine requested for the laundry is also recommended. At the present time, if they wish to wash a few dish towels or something of that kind they have to turn on the big machines in the laundry and require the services of the engineer and the matron to oversee the work.

In regard to painting the residences and barns, this of course can be delayed if funds are not available, however, the painting is very badly needed.

Yours truly,

I am enclosing herewith letter from Mr. Staley, Principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School requesting permission to make some alterations in the horse barn at the school.

This is a large veneer barn with metal stalls for 16 horses, 8' on each side of the barn as well as several box stalls. At the time the barn was built all the farm work was done with horses and accommodation for quite a large number was required; however, the work is now done by tractor and I do not think there is any possibility of their going back to horse labour. At the present time the farm has 6 horses which are very seldom used. Mr. Staley has the cow barn filled up at present and has considerable young stock. It is his intention to increase the herd if possible and he would like to have permission to remove the horse stalls from one side of the horse barn and replace them with cow stalls where he can stable his dry milk cows and young stock.

If alterations of this kind can be permitted would you please advise and I will secure and forward an estimate of the cost.

E.A. Robertson,
Superintendent.

Dear Sir:

On Monday night Oct. 25 about eight o'clock smoke was noticed coming from the laundry and when the door was opened a blaze of quite large proportions was discovered. After a two hour fight the flames were subdued and it was found that apparently the fire had started in a cupboard containing soaps and other laundry materials. We were actually at a loss to determine its real cause but judging by the charred and blackened appearance of the wall and ceiling the wooden cupboard contained the start of the difficulty. The flames got a good hold on the ceiling and holes had to be cut through the flat upper roof to fight the blaze.

The children in the meantime had all been alerted and dressed and were standing in the corridors of the main building awaiting the outcome of the fight.

The fire was happily confined to the laundry but considerable damage was done. The ceiling will need extensive repairs and all the belting on the machinery was destroyed while the electric wiring for the whole school was interfered with. I was unable of course to get in touch with you but reported the matter to your office on Tuesday morning and also phoned Mr. Gooderham.

I was compelled to deal immediately with the electrical problem in order to carry on the regular work of the school and because the fused wiring was threatening further trouble and I also ordered belting for the machines because without the belts it was quite impossible to tell what damage if any had been done to the machinery. I am not as yet able to report on this matter.

In conversation with Mr. Battle in Calgary he advised that any further repairs should await the consent of Ottawa. At present I would judge the amount of damage to be $350.00 to the laundry while the school lost $500.00 worth of clothing. (Copy of letter is going forward to Calgary office.)

Yours truly,

E. J. Staley.

RE: Fire at Edmonton Residential School.

Further to Mr. Gooderham's letter of Oct. 27, to you in connection with the above.

On my return to the office from Lac La Biche on Friday, Oct. 29th, I was advised of the fire in the laundry at Edmonton School on Oct. 25th, and went to the School to inspect the damage on Saturday, Oct. 30.

From the appearance of the room, I would agree with Mr. Staley's suggestion that it started in a cupboard containing soap and cleaning compounds, but whether it started from spontaneous combustion or from defective wiring or some other cause, it would be impossible to say.

The cupboard and one or two tables in the laundry were completely destroyed. All belting for the machines was also burned. The electric wiring and all switches and outlets were destroyed and all the window glass was shattered and will have to be replaced. The room has a metal ceiling and the heat burned all the paint from this.

One or two wooden pulleys may have to replaced later but the machines do not appear to have been damaged.

In fighting the fire it was necessary to cut several holes in the roof in order to get at the fire in the boards under the metal ceiling but the cost of repairing the roof will be very small.
Mr. Neary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Neary:

On the night of Monday Oct. 25th our night man on duty going his rounds about seven forty five discovered smoke seeping from the laundry. He raised the alarm and alerted the staff and children and then opened the laundry room door to be greeted by a solid mass of flame and smoke. A two hour fight resulted in the blaze being brought under control but not before considerable damage being done to the laundry. Investigation showed that the fire had broken out in a wooden cupboard used for storing soaps and other light materials. How the fire started I do not think will ever be known because everything wooden in the room was destroyed together with some $500 worth of clothing. The room had been used all day and had been inspected at six and at seven o'clock and at these hours there was no sign of anything out of order. The fire was put out largely because of the changes made by your department that resulted in our having an automatic pump to keep the pressure up. A year ago the building would have burned down.

I would like to comment too, on the excellent behaviour of the children which augers well if any further difficulty should arise.

I have taken up the matter of repairs with your office and feel sure that the figure of $350 I mentioned will be close to the actual amount needed to fully restore the department.

I have of course taken all the precautions I can to see that an efficient system of inspection and control be put into operation to prevent any further difficulty.

Yours truly,

E. J. Staley,
(Principal)

Re: Edmonton Residential School - Donald Inspection Company Report
Ref. your I.A. 1656-12 of November 26

The report on this school submitted by the Donald Inspection Company has received careful consideration here. It would seem that we will have to consider the following major expenditures at this school next year:

(a) Plumbing - installation of drinking fountain and toilet near dormitories,

(b) Fire Escapes - installation of tubular or other type escapes,

(c) Water Supply - replacement of present tanks by elevated water tanks,

(d) Heating - installation of two new boilers,

(e) Spires - removal of metal work above the louvers. Such spires were always installed in our Residential Schools built in the 1920's and '30's, and we consider that they are no longer necessary.

(f) Laundry - replacement of present laundry machinery,

(g) Sewage Disposal - installation of an additional septic tank.
I would like to recommend that a meeting be held between our Education Officials and those of your Engineering and Construction Service so that a decision can be reached as to the best way of having this school brought into an efficient state of repair. It will probably be necessary to have a fairly substantial sum placed in our 1949-50 Supplementary Estimates for the various items mentioned above.

I do not think that public opinion would exactly agree with the lessening of vigilance at a place like this and I do not think that the Provincial laws will much longer tolerate conditions at our Institution that are so obviously sub standard judged by other buildings.

May I request again that an adequate water reserve system be provided, either over or in the attic, that all exits be equipped with panic bolts, that the fire escapes be made usable instead of as at present, just ugly pieces of iron work fastened to the building.

Dear Sir:

I have yours of recent date re salary of night watchman at Edmonton Indian School.

I am somewhat amazed at what is said because it reveals such a lack of knowledge of what this building is really like. No school anywhere is likely to be more of a death trap than this if fire really gets going. Just a few months ago, a fire was discovered by the alertness of the night watchman, that could easily have destroyed the whole place. Its origin is not known but it was only put out with extreme difficulty.

It might be well if you and Mr. Gooderham were consulted before there is any thought of cutting off the small pittance that is now given. You, at least know what the situation is while the writer very evidently knows nothing except the financial obligation.

It would be very wise to call the attention of the Dept. to the visit and recommendation of the Provincial Fire Inspector made in the fall of 1946. Nothing has been done to remedy the main faults of that time. The water supply is useless to meet any size blaze. If the fire is not found and controlled in a few minutes the case is hopeless. There is a trickle of water in the attic, a few minutes supply on the top floor and so it goes.

The fire escape are antiquated and useless. In winter, the children have to climb out through windows three feet from the floor, then down a frozen pole to the ground, many feet below.

Memorandum re Sewage Disposal - Edmonton Residential School
Edmonton, Alberta

Examined February 14, 1949

This residential school for Indian children from central Alberta is located on a farm four miles north of the City of Edmonton. At present there is a staff of 14 persons and 150 pupils. The school is operated by the United Church of Canada with financial aid from the Dominion Government.

Sewage from the school and three residences flows into a three-chamber septic tank, then into a low, fenced area some 300 yards from the school and 100 yards from the nearest barn. The septic tank was installed in 1923 when the school was built and is of poor design. Entering sewage flows to twin chambers each 12 feet square and only two feet deep, then through a chamber 12 feet long, 24 feet wide, and 4 feet deep. The capacity of the tanks (10,800 gals.) is approximately correct for the population (175) but the design is such that the influent passes quickly through the three compartments without allowing sufficient time for deposition of suspended matter or providing suitable conditions for sludge digestion. The first two compartments are shallow, and built-up sludge forms a channel to the third compartment which allows the sewage to flow across its least dimension.

The disposal pond creates a nuisance in the summer time for odors reach the school. The laundry drain bypasses the septic tank. Drains from the school have been plugged four times in the last fifteen months, probably due to settling and cracking of the tile.

Conclusions and Recommendations

It is believed if the sewage received better treatment before discharge into the pond, the odor would not be so noticeable. This could be accomplished by construction of a septic tank of good design which would give a better degree of treatment than the present one.

However, odors would still arise and it is preferable that the effluent be piped further away. To the northwest there is a large, suitable flat area covered with trees. Some 250 yards of pipe would be required to discharge the effluent into a gully which flows to the flat area. Levels need to be run to determine the exact length of pipe and depth of trench.

It is recommended that:

1. The existing sewer from the school to the septic tank be replaced.
2. A suitable septic tank of proper design be constructed.
3. The septic tank effluent be discharged to the pond northwest of the barn.

Stanley Epp
Sanitary Engineer, District No. 8.

Memorandum re Water Supply, Edmonton Residential School
Edmonton, Alberta.

Examined February 14, 1949.

This residential school for Indian children from Central Alberta is located on a farm four miles north of the City of Edmonton. At present there is a staff of fourteen persons and an enrolment of 150 pupils. The school is operated by the United Church of Canada with financial aid from the Dominion Government.

Water is supplied from a drilled well 180 feet deep, in which the water rises 75 feet. The hole is steel cased with 6 inch casing at the bottom and 8 inch at the top. It is drilled through sedimentary strata containing hardpan and numerous coal seams. An electrically-operated Myer's pump produces a flow of 25 to 40 gallons per minute to two 1200 gallon pressure tanks in which a pressure of 25 - 45 pounds per square inch is maintained. This is the only storage provided and there is not sufficient fire protection since the well will not produce water at a sufficient rate to maintain pressure for water to reach the top storey.

Four samples of water taken from the distribution system (see attached sheet) indicated the water to be of good bacteriological quality. The attached chemical analysis shows the water to be of fair chemical quality since it has a total dissolved solids of over 2300 p.p.m., which is largely sodium sulphate. However, the water is quite soft and when it is cold the soda is not unduly noticed.

Conclusions and Recommendations.

The water at this residential school appears to be satisfactory bacteriologically and since water is very scarce in the area with no streams or springs nearby, the present water supply, although only of fair chemical quality, should be satisfactory. An elevated storage tank would be protection against fire since the present supply could not combat one successfully.

Stanley S. Popp
Sanitary Engineer, District No. 8.

Memorandum

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School,
Winterburn, Alta.

In accordance with a request from Major MacKay our heating engineer visited the above on his recent inspection trip to Alberta and British Columbia, and the following report is submitted for your information and transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch.

This school is twenty-six (26) years old and is in fairly good condition. However, due to a number of reasons, hereinafter outlined, several major items of mechanical equipment have simultaneously reached a stage of deterioration where costly operations will be required within a short time if these services are to function with reasonable efficiency.

The heating system does not give satisfaction. Practically all rooms farthest away from the boilers are difficult to heat. As is the case with a number of other schools, it can be stated that the principal reason is due to the original faulty design of the piping system. This design was based on a so-called vapour system which is supposed to operate on several ounces of pressure. In a building of this size satisfactory distribution of steam cannot be realized on such low pressures, and when the pressure is increased the steam simply short circuits through bleeder connections taken from the ends of the mains and connected to a system of wet returns and consequently the radiators near the ends of the mains and branch mains receive little or no steam.

This system can be made to function satisfactorily by the installation of float and thermostatic traps on the ends of all mains and branch mains. These traps will prevent short circuiting and since the steam cannot get into the returns, it must pass through radiators as it should. In addition to that feature of the system, it was found that the condensation was returned to the boilers through what is now considered to be an obsolete arrangement consisting of a boiler return trap and air eliminator assembly. This equipment must be replaced by a modern and inexpensive condensation pump and receiver together with minor piping changes in the boiler room. With this set-up normal operating pressures of one to two lbs. per square inch can be used and the problem of distribution overcome.

The heating system is powered by two Pascol steel fire box low pressure steam heating boilers each rated at approximately 48 H.P. These boilers were condemned several years ago by the Provincial Boiler Inspector, but since it was impossible at that time to obtain new boilers extensive and somewhat unusual repairs were carried out to permit the boilers to remain in service. One boiler had a complete new base welded.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
on. It can be stated that at present they are in somewhat less than fair condition and cannot be expected to give further satisfactory service.

The domestic hot and cold water system has also been a source of trouble for a number of years. There are two 1200 gallon water pressure tanks located in a space adjacent to the boiler room. Water is pumped from a well into these tanks and distribution from the tanks is made to the various parts of the building and to several adjacent residences. The piping going to the residences is undersized, and fixtures on the second floor are for the most part inoperative. The tanks which have been in since the school was built are in bad shape. They have been patched and welded on various occasions and the time has arrived when they can no longer be successfully repaired and it naturally follows that they will have to be replaced at as early a date as possible. The distribution piping is in a critical state. Many sections of hot and cold water lines have been replaced from time to time by the operating engineer until the system is now a mess of patchwork. A chemical element in the water has corroded this steel piping to such an extent that innumerable pin holes and leaks of all kinds are in evidence throughout the entire system. It will likely be found when this water is analyzed that copper piping will be required for the new work.

The sewage disposal system has been a constant source of trouble for many years. The septic tank is of a unique and somewhat unorthodox design and instead of being buried in the ground in accordance with generally accepted principles, it is installed at grade level and is provided with a frame roof which is far from being tight or waterproof. No evidence of bacterial action was to be found. The siphons were reported to be continually blocked and this is not surprising in view of the fact that the raw sewage due to a lack of bacterial action is not broken down into a liquid. The raw sewage overflows into a discharge line laid in tile underground and carried to a slough about 250 to 300 yards away from the school. This slough is nothing less than a huge cess pit and bad odours are wafted towards the school and the surrounding buildings according to the caprices of the wind. This results in an abominable condition and in spite of efforts to keep the tank clean only temporary relief has been gained. This tank will have to be abandoned and replaced by one of a proper design.

Most of the W.C.'s in the boys section in the basement have been practically ruined by what appears to be willful destruction. It is evident that a lack of proper supervision is responsible for the condition of these fixtures. In most cases the porcelain is cracked and huge chips broken leaving the battery of fixtures in a sorry state.

No drinking fountains were provided in the dormitory section on the top floor and this has resulted in a hardship for the pupils in residence during the night.

In addition to the foregoing there are numerous other minor items all in a state of progressive deterioration, and it is evident that operations on a major scale will be required if this school is to continue operations.
It is therefore recommended that the following operations be carried out.

(a) Provide one new steel fire box low pressure steam heating boiler and thoroughly repair the other existing boiler for standby use.

(b) Provide new condensation pump and receiver unit.

(c) Provide and install float and thermostatic traps on ends of all steam mains and branch mains.

(d) Provide several additional radiators in rooms which are insufficiently heated.

(e) Replace the entire domestic hot and cold water system of piping.

(f) Replace the two existing cold water pressure tanks.

(g) Build new concrete septic tank.

(h) Install several drinking fountains.

Until a layout has been prepared it will be most difficult to estimate the cost of these operations. It can be safely assumed however that this work will cost in the neighbourhood of Twenty Five Thousand Dollars ($25,000.00), and it can again be stated that every item previously mentioned is vitally necessary.

When approval is received to proceed with the design and specifications covering the revisions outlined, we will prepare a layout as soon as possible.

Chas. H. Buck,
for Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.
Ottawa, July 18th, 1949.

ALTERATIONS AND REVISIONS TO
STEAM HEATING, DOMESTIC HOT AND COLD WATER AND
SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS

1. SCOPE OF WORK

This specification and the accompanying plans Index No. 917,
Sheets No. M1/4, M2/4, M3/4, and M4/4, are intended to provide for
such alterations and revisions to the heating, domestic hot and cold
water, and sewage disposal systems for the building mentioned as in-
dicated under the following sub-headings:-

(a) Disconnect and remove existing boilers.

(b) Disconnect and remove existing boiler return trap
and air eliminator assembly.

(c) Provide and install two (2) new steel boilers and
piping thereto, as shown on plans.

(d) Provide and install new condensation pump and re-
ceiver with motor, where noted on plans.

(e) Provide and install new float and thermostatic
traps etc., on steam and branch mains, where noted
on plans.

(f) Provide and install stoker under boiler where shown
on plans.

(g) Provide and install stoker controls and pressure
gauge.

(h) Provide and install new steam heating piping, risers,
etc., where shown on plans.

(i) Provide and install new and additional radiation where
noted on plans.

(j) Provide and install new domestic hot water storage tank,
where noted on plans.

(k) Provide and install new indirect steam fed heater where
shown on plans.

(l) Provide and install new temperature control unit for hot
water supply as noted on plans.

(m) Remove all domestic hot and cold water mains, branch mains,
risers etc., in school building and residences.

(n) Provide and install new copper domestic hot and cold water
distribution system in school as shown on plans and re-
place piping in residences.

(o) Provide and install new drinking fountains in first floor
dormitories.

(p) Badly damaged W.C.'s in Boys' Lavatory to be removed and
replaced.

(q) Disconnect and remove existing hydro-pneumatic tanks and
replace with new as hereinafter specified.

(r) Boiler room opening to be enlarged and finished as detailed
on plans.

(s) Construct a new reinforced concrete ramp to new Boiler
Room opening.
(t) Construct, and connect to existing sewage system, new septic tank, as detailed on plans.

(u) All miscellaneous items required to complete the revisions as noted on plan or hereinafter specified, or as may be required, shall be supplied under this contract.

The Contractor shall take all measurements at the buildings and site, set out the work and be responsible for the accuracy of the same. He shall provide all labour, transportation, materials and plant, and give his personal and constant attention to the work, and be responsible for any damage done, including damage to any part of the building incident to the installation of the work.

2. VISIT THE SITE

The Contractor must visit the Site and see the conditions under which the work will be done and govern himself accordingly.

3. MATERIALS AND WORKMANSHIP

All materials shall be new and the best of their respective kinds, sound and free from defects.

All connections shall be made so as to permit free and unobstructed flow at all times, with adequate provision for expansion, and due attention given to the grading of pipes.

All work shall be executed in a neat and workmanlike manner by workmen skilled in this trade, and special attention shall be given to exposed work so that it be neatly erected with pipes plumb and true.

4. RULES AND REGULATIONS

All work shall be done in accordance with rules, regulations and recommendations as may be laid down by local or other authorities controlling such work. This Contractor shall file all necessary plans with such authorities and pay all necessary fees for permits, etc., as may be required.

5. NEW BOILER ROOM INSTALLATIONS

New installations in boiler room shall be located as detailed. Existing installations, where retained, shall be suitably relocated when, and if, necessary.

6. SEQUENCE OF WORK

The new hydro-pneumatic tanks shall be installed prior to the installation of the new boilers.

7. GRADING OF PIPES

All new horizontal branches of hot and cold water piping shall be so graded that they may be completely drained through drip connections which shall be installed at necessary points.

All new steam and return mains shall be graded to $1/4"$ in 10 feet in direction noted on plan.

All new spring pieces and horizontal laterals to radiators shall be graded to $1/2"$ per foot back to main.

8. CUTTING AND PATCHING

The Contractor shall be responsible for all cutting of holes through walls, floors, ceilings and roofs, incident to his work and shall be required to patch up to match existing wall, floor, ceiling
and roof finishes in the area affected. Skilled workmen shall be employed for this work and it shall be carried out to the satisfaction of the representative of the Department.

9. PIPING

All steam piping and return mains shall be standard black steel pipe put together with cast-iron screwed fittings, with eccentric couplings and unions, screwed or flanged where required; all pipe shall be carefully reamed before assembly and pipe compound applied to pipe threads only. New pipes only shall be used in the boiler room. New risers and take-offs for radiators may be cut and welded into existing main.

No changes or additions to the fire protection service including fire lines, stand pipes, hoses etc., are contemplated.

Disconnect and remove all domestic hot, cold and recirculating water mains, branch mains, risers and branches under upper floors to fixtures. Disconnect and plug all mains, branches, etc., which may be under basement floor slabs.

Provide and install new domestic hot and cold water distribution system consisting of mains, branch mains; risers etc., of type "K" or "L" copper pipe with streamline fittings. The copper piping shall start at the pressure tanks. Galvanized wrought steel pipe is permitted for connections between new domestic hot water storage tank and heater. Mains in basement shall be exposed near basement ceiling. All connections to fixtures shall be fitted with air chambers not less than 12" long as shown on detail. All new piping to be of sizes shown on drawings, and distribution shall be made substantially as indicated.

The existing domestic hot water tank and Bungalow heater shall be connected to the new system in such a manner that they may be used for summer service when boilers are shut down.

A new water main leading to the residences of 1/4" copper shall be installed and the supply pipe to each residence shall be 1" diameter. Mains in the residences shall be 3/4" and suitable distribution made therefrom.

The main to the residences shall be below grade to avoid all chances of frost, i.e. a minimum of 6" below deepest frost line.

10. HOSE BIBBS

One hose bibb shall be installed in the boiler room and existing hose bibbs connected as required. These bibbs shall be one-half inch angle pattern hose valve with renewable seat and tee handle. Where hose bibbs are outside, install a combination shut-off and draincut valve on line inside the building.

11. COVERING

All new exposed cold water piping, unless otherwise noted, shall be covered 1" thick with anti-sweat wool felt sectional covering consisting of two 1/2" layers, each of which shall have been so fabricated by its manufacturer as to have a double thickness of asphalt paper both inside and out, stapled in place and jacketted with factory cotton pasted on.

All hot water supply pipes, unless otherwise noted, shall be covered with 1" thick 4-ply asbestos aircell sectional pipe covering carefully butted and fitted around hangers, etc., and jacketted with factory cotton pasted on.

Elbows, tees, valves, etc., shall be covered with asbestos cement and covered with cotton as specified for pipes.
The new hot water storage tank with new heater shall be covered with 1" thick 4-ply asbestos air cell blocks, wired in place, and plastered 1" thick with long fibre asbestos cement applied in two coats, the last coat to be tempered with 10 per cent (10%) Portland cement and trowelled to a smooth finish. Paint two coats with waterproof paint of an approved colour.

All new steam mains shall be covered with 4-ply 1" thick asbestos air cell sectional pipe covering carefully butted and fitted around hangers where such occur, finished with factory cotton pasted on. Elbows, tees, valves, etc., shall be covered with long fibre asbestos cement wrapped with cotton as specified for pipes. Flanges, unions and return mains need not be covered unless so noted on plan.

12. VALVES

Valves generally shall be gate valves unless otherwise mentioned, 2" and under shall be all brass. Over 2" shall be iron body valves with bronze trimmings.

13. TESTING

Water piping. Contractor will test all water piping before covering, using cold water at 100 lb. pressure.

14. HANGERS

Horizontal runs of water piping shall be supported at 8'-0" intervals with rod and ring hangers. No grabbler bar allowed.

15. FLOAT AND THERMOSTATIC TRAPS

Provide and install on steam and branch mains, as detailed on plan, new float and thermostatic traps of an approved type complete with all valves, strainers, scale pockets unions etc., connect to existing wet return lines. Trap capacity at the water heater shall be as noted on plan.

16. RADIATION

Additional sections shall be connected to 36 existing radiators in the number and manner noted and detailed on plans.

New radiators shall be installed where and as noted and detailed on plans.

(i) In basement - 6 new legless 2 column radiators wall hung as noted on plan.

(ii) Ground floor - 5 new radiators of 2 column free standing type as detailed on plan.

(iii) First floor - 8 new radiators of 2 column free standing type and 1 sectional wall radiator to match existing wall radiator in room.

17. RISERS, STUBS, SPRING PIECES, ETC.

Where shown on plans new and renewed steam risers, spring pieces etc., numbering 14 in all, shall be installed in the sizes noted. Only 4 new condensate return stubs are required as shown on plan.

18. RADIATOR VALVES AND TRAPS

New radiator valves shall be equal to C.A. Dunham Type 140 series, bellows packless with wood wheel handle.
Traps shall be equal to C.A. Dunham standard thermostatic type for normal operating pressures up to 5 lbs gauge and not exceeding 15 pounds pressure.

19. DOMESTIC HOT WATER STORAGE TANK

Provide and install one Domestic Hot Water Storage Tank where and as noted on plan. Pressure Relief Valve shall be installed where shown on plan, and set at 70 p.s.i.

20. DOMESTIC HOT WATER HEATER

Provide and install as noted on plan, new indirect steam fed heater with cast iron shell and removable copper tube element equal to type "JU" Alco as made by Arthur S. Leitch Co., Ltd., of Canada. Connect with new domestic hot water storage tank, providing all necessary valves and fittings as shown or as may be required.

Provide and install on steam line to heater one self-contained temperature regulating valve Equal to Powers No. 11, with dial thermometer and temperature adjustment complete with bulb and tube, as noted on plan.

21. DOMESTIC HOT WATER STORAGE TANK STAND

Provide and install new domestic hot water storage tank stand consisting of six (6) upright 2" steel pipes with flanged base supports and capped ends. These shall be braced in both directions.

22. STOKER CONTROL

Provide and install new, pressure gauges on new boilers complete with necessary siphon. Provide and install new pressure-trol on stoker fired boiler to control operation of newly installed stoker. This pressure-trol is to be set to cut stoker in at two and one-half (2½) pounds pressure, and out at four and one-half (4½) pounds pressure.

23. CONDENSATION PUMP

The Contractor shall remove existing boiler return trap and air eliminator assembly.

Provide, install where shown on plan, and connect new condensation pump equal to C.A. Dunham Co., Ltd., #C.H.1015 having a capacity of 10,000 square feet E.D.R. Pump shall be complete with motor (1/2) H.P. (110-220 volts single phase A.C.) welded steel tank, equipped with float switch and mounting saddles, mounted on integral base. Connect all returns to new pump and receiver.

24. BOILERS

Disconnect and remove existing two (2) boilers.

Provide and install two (2) new steel firebox boilers where, and as noted on plans. Connections to boiler room equipment shall be substantially as detailed on plans. Set each boiler on 12" brick base. Boilers shall be equal to Calor SO 541 as made by E. Leonard and Sons Ltd., having a capacity of 7391 E.D.R. net. Boilers must have smoke breeching at rear.

The right-hand boiler shall be equipped with grates having an area of 22 square feet, for hand firing.

25. SMOKE BREECHING

Provide and erect new smoke breeching of sizes shown on detail. Breeching shall be made up of #16 U.S. gauge black steel suitably reinforced with 1½" x 1/8" angles and provided with cleanouts where shown.
26. AUTOMATIC BOILER FEEDWATER REGULATORS

Provide and install, where shown on plan, automatic boiler feedwater regulators of an approved make, and of size in accordance with manufacturer's recommendation, designed to definitely maintain boiler water level at all times. Regulators to be furnished with low water cut-off and cold water supply for boiler connected thereto.

27. STOKER INSTALLATION

Provide and install new screw feed underfeed stoker under Boiler where shown on plan. Stoker shall be equal to Iron Fireman Series 31 Standard Hopper Model, No. 4, having a maximum capacity of 300 lbs of coal per hour. The motor shall be 2 H.P., having suitable electrical characteristics. Installation shall be in accordance to manufacturers instructions and requirements. Stoker shall be furnished with steel hopper with feed wheel, cast alloy worm in steel having removable inspection plate, and first quality gear box, with feed adjustment from high to low in steps.

28. DRINKING FOUNTAINS (4 REQUIRED)

Install where noted on plan, in dormitories, porcelain enamelled cast-iron wall fountain with 11" bowl, chromium plated angle stream jet, strainer and ¾" male connection, having chromium plated brass supply with loose key stop. Waste pipe 1¼" with adjustable "P" trap. Connect to nearby waste main, running pipe exposed.

29. CLOSET COMBINATION (3 REQUIRED)

Contractor shall remove W.C.'s in Boys' Basement Lavatory. Replacements shall be new.

Vitreous china reverse trap elongated rim bowl with cast iron floor flange asbestos gasket and china bolt caps.

New Vitreous china low down closet tank with silent ball cock and 3/8" galvanized angle supply with rough plated brass stop and wall flange.

New Black Bonalite open front seat less cover with plated bar hinge.

30. MANUFACTURERS' PLATE NUMBERS AND ILLUSTRATIONS

The Contractor shall submit in quadruplicate a list of the Plumbing Fixtures and Fittings with Manufacturers' Plate Numbers and Illustrations that he proposes to supply to the Department for approval. Fixtures and Fittings shall be as specified consistent with such restrictions as may apply; for any such not obtainable the Contractor shall submit obtainable and acceptable alternative subject to the final approval of the Department.

31. HYDRO PNEUMATIC TANKS

Disconnect and remove existing hydro-pneumatic tanks and replace with two new steel hydro-pneumatic tanks 45' x 18'-0" long, capacity approximately 1200 Imperial gallons, built to withstand 100 lbs working pressure. Tanks shall each be equipped with a manhole and water and air openings placed for convenient piping when set on saddles. Each tank shall be equipped with two (2) glass water gauges each not exceeding 18" in length. All tappings to be bossed.

32. SEPTIC TANK

Construct a new septic tank where shown on plot plan in accordance with the drawings. The sewage shall be diverted from nearby manhole into new septic tank and the effluent cut into existing effluent main at a convenient point past the old septic tank. Levels shall be taken from invert of existing manhole and carried through to point where
effluent from new tank enters existing effluent main, to ensure proper flow at all times, and to establish the depth below grade for new septic tank. The drop in the main between manhole and new tank shall be at least 2" in 10'-0". Waste from laundry shall by-pass both septic tanks. The new tank shall be positioned so as to avoid existing rainwater and laundry waste by-pass.

35. EXISTING SEPTIC TANK

Disconnect existing pipe and close opening in manhole when new septic tank is in operation.

Remove roof of existing septic tank and fill with earth excavated from new tank location, and abandon.

34. CONCRETE

(a) For Septic Tank

To be class "A" in the proportions of 1 part Portland cement, 1½ parts coarse clean sand and 2 parts of broken stone not exceeding 1½" in size, and 4½ Imperial gallons of water including surface water in the aggregate. The concrete shall develop 3000 pounds per square inch compressive strength at 28 days and be of watertight density.

(b) For Ramp - Retaining Wall

To be class "B" in the proportions of 1 part Portland cement 1½ parts coarse clean sand and 3 part broken stone not exceeding 1½" in size and 5.10 Imperial gallons of water including surface water in the aggregate. The concrete shall develop 2500 pounds per square inch compressive strength at 28 days.

35. REINFORCING STEEL

For concrete shall be of intermediate grade rail or billet steel and shall comply with the standard specification of the Canadian Engineering Specifications Association.

36. NEW OPENING TO BOILER ROOM AND RAMP

Remove existing window and break out wall to make new opening and concrete ramp as detailed on plan. Provide and install doors, glazing, kick plates etc., as detailed or as may be required. Brickwork and concrete around opening shall be made good.

37. DRAINAGE AT RAMP

Place one floor drain in concrete slab at bottom of ramp and connect to existing weeping tile drain at building footing.

38. CONTROL EQUIPMENT

The Contractor shall furnish and mount where shown on plan, or where directed, all thermostats, aquastats, and other automatic electrical or other control equipment for temperature and pressure regulation, of approved manufacture, suitable capacity and electrical characteristics in accordance with details, shown on plan or specified, or as may be required. All wiring will be done by the Electrical Contractor.

39. SHOP DRAWINGS

Shop drawings shall be submitted in quadruplicate for approval to the Department, of boilers and stoker with settings.
40. **COMPLETION**

Upon completion of the work, the Contractor shall remove all rubbish and waste materials resulting from his work and leave the whole system in perfect working order.

41. **RECORD PLANS**

During the progress of the work the Contractor shall keep a record of all changes to the original plans.

Upon completion of the work the Contractor shall turn over one set of signed blueprints to the representative of the Department at the time of his inspection, with such changes clearly recorded in red. Blueprints for this purpose will be furnished by the Department.

42. **GUARANTEE**

The Contractor will be called upon to guarantee his work for a period of one year after date of acceptance by the owner. He shall make good or replace any defect arising in his work during that period, at his own expense and as soon as possible after having been notified in writing that such defect occurs.

GENERAL CONDITIONS

The work outlined in this specification and shown on the accompanying drawings, namely, Index No. 917, Sheets No. M1/4, M2/4, M3/4 and M4/4, are intended to be carried out by a General Contractor, who, in this case, shall be the Steamfitter. He shall engage all necessary sub-contractors and skilled mechanics to do all work not relative to his own and shall be responsible for the successful carrying out and completion of all the work involved.

As this project is of an urgent nature, the Contractor will be required to engage skilled men in the numbers required to carry out the work as quickly as possible.

The Department will not enter into any correspondence with sub-contractors or tradesmen; all such matters pertaining to the job as may arise during the course of the work shall be between the General Contractor and the Department.

In submitting his estimate covering the complete installation, the General Contractor shall enclose his marked cheque for ten per cent, (10%) of the amount made payable to the Receiver General of Canada. At the time a contract is awarded, cheques will be returned to unsuccessful contractors.

Progress payments up to ninety per cent (90%) of the approximate value of the work based on monthly progress estimates, will be made at monthly intervals, with the remaining ten per cent (10%) being retained as a holdback until final completion and acceptance of the work by the Department.

Only work shown on the plan and/or included in the specification is authorized. No observations or conflicting instructions from personnel not connected with the Engineering and Construction Division, are to be recognized.

In order to accelerate progress of the work, the Department is prepared to render such constructive advice as the Contractor may require during the progress of the work.

All correspondence with the Department and documents mentioned herein, shall be addressed to:

C. Victor F. Weir,
Chief,
Engineering and Construction Division,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Pump shall be complete with motor (1/2) H.P. (110-220 volts single phase A.C.) welded steel tank, equipped with float switch and mounting saddles, mounted on integral base. Connect all returns to new pump and receiver.

24. BOILERS

Disconnect and remove existing two (2) boilers.

Provide and install two (2) new steel firebox boilers where, and as noted on plans. Connections to boiler room equipment shall be substantially as detailed on plans. Set each boiler on 12" brick base. Boilers shall be equal to Calor SO 541 as made by E. Leonard and Sons Ltd., having a capacity of 7391 E.D.R. net. Boilers must have smoke breeching at rear.

The right-hand boiler shall be equipped with grates having an area of 22 square feet, for hand firing.

25. SMOKE BREECHING

Provide and erect new smoke breeching of sizes shown on detail. Breeching shall be made up of #16 U.S. gauge black steel suitably reinforced with 1½" x 1/8" angles and provided with cleanouts where shown.
26. AUTOMATIC BOILER FEEDWATER REGULATORS

Provide and install, where shown on plan, automatic boiler feedwater regulators of an approved make, and of size in accordance with manufacturer's recommendation, designed to definitely maintain boiler water level at all times. Regulators to be furnished with low water cut-off and cold water supply for boiler connected thereto.

27. STOKER INSTALLATION

Provide and install new screw feed underfeed stoker under Boiler where shown on plan. Stoker shall be equal to Iron Fireman Series 31 Standard Hopper Model, No. 4, having a maximum capacity of 300 lbs of coal per hour. The motor shall be 2 H.P. having suitable electrical characteristics. Installation shall be in accordance to manufacturers instructions and requirements. Stoker shall be furnished with steel hopper with feed wheel, cast alloy worm in steel having removable inspection plate, and first quality gear box, with feed adjustment from high to low in steps.

28. DRINKING FOUNTAINS (4 REQUIRED)

Install where noted on plan, in dormitories, porcelain enamelled cast-iron wall fountain with 11" bowl, chromium plated angle stream jet, strainer and ¾" male connection, having chromium plated brass supply with loose key stop. Waste pipe 1¼" with adjustable "P" trap. Connect to nearby waste main, running pipe exposed.

29. CLOSET COMBINATION (3 REQUIRED)

Contractor shall remove W.C.'s in Boys' Basement Lavatory. Replacements shall be new.

Vitreous china reverse trap elongated rim bowl with cast iron floor flange asbestos gasket and china bolt caps.

New Vitreous china low down closet tank with silent ball cock and 3/8" galvanized angle supply with rough plated brass stop and wall flange.

New Black Bonalite open front seat less cover with plated bar hinge.

30. MANUFACTURERS' PLATE NUMBERS AND ILLUSTRATIONS

The Contractor shall submit in quadruplicate a list of the Plumbing Fixtures and Fittings with Manufacturers' Plate Numbers and Illustrations that he proposes to supply to the Department for approval. Fixtures and Fittings shall be as specified consistent with such restrictions as may apply; for any such not obtainable the Contractor shall submit obtainable and acceptable alternative subject to the final approval of the Department.

31. HYDRO PNEUMATIC TANKS

Disconnect and remove existing hydro-pneumatic tanks and replace with two new steel hydro-pneumatic tanks 45" x 18'-0" long, capacity approximately 1200 Imperial gallons, built to withstand 100 lbs. working pressure. Tanks shall each be equipped with a manhole and water and air openings placed for convenient piping when set on saddles. Each tank shall be equipped with two (2) glass water gauges each not exceeding 18" in length. All tapping to be bossed.

32. SEPTIC TANK

Construct a new septic tank where shown on plot plan in accordance with the drawings. The sewage shall be diverted from nearby manhole into new septic tank and the effluent cut into existing effluent main at a convenient point past the old septic tank. Levels shall be taken from invert of existing manhole and carried through to point where
effluent from new tank enters existing effluent main, to ensure proper flow at all times, and to establish the depth below grade for new septic tank. The drop in the main between manhole and new tank shall be at least 2" in 10'-0". Waste from laundry shall by-pass both septic tanks. The new tank shall be positioned so as to avoid existing rainwater and laundry waste by-pass.

33. EXISTING SEPTIC TANK

Disconnect existing pipe and close opening in manhole when new septic tank is in operation.

Remove roof of existing septic tank and fill with earth excavated from new tank location, and abandon.

34. CONCRETE

(a) For Septic Tank

To be class "A" in the proportions of 1 part Portland cement, 1\(\frac{1}{2}\) parts coarse clean sand and 1 parts of broken stone not exceeding 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" in size, and 4\(\frac{1}{2}\)'Imperial gallons of water including surface water in the aggregate. The concrete shall develop 3000 pounds per square inch compressive strength at 28 days and be of watertight density.

(b) For Ramp - Retaining Wall

To be class "B" in the proportions of 1 part Portland cement 1\(\frac{1}{2}\) parts coarse clean sand and 3 part broken stone not exceeding 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" in size and 5,10' Imperial gallons of water including surface water in the aggregate. The concrete shall develop 2500 pounds per square inch compressive strength at 28 days.

35. REINFORCING STEEL

For concrete shall be of intermediate grade rail or billet steel and shall comply with the standard specification of the Canadian Engineering Specifications Association.

36. NEW OPENING TO BOILER ROOM AND RAMP

Remove existing window and break out wall to make new opening and concrete ramp as detailed on plan. Provide and install doors, glazing, kick plates etc., as detailed or as may be required. Brickwork and concrete around opening shall be made good.

37. DRAINAGE AT RAMP

Place one floor drain in concrete slab at bottom of ramp and connect to existing weeping tile drain at building footing.

38. CONTROL EQUIPMENT

The Contractor shall furnish and mount where shown on plan, or where directed, all thermostats, aquastats, and other automatic electrical or other control equipment for temperature and pressure regulation, of approved manufacture, suitable capacity and electrical characteristics in accordance with details, shown on plan or specified, or as may be required. All wiring will be done by the Electrical Contractor.

39. SHOP DRAWINGS

Shop drawings shall be submitted in quadruplicate for approval to the Department, of boilers and stoker with settings.
40. COMPLETION

Upon completion of the work, the Contractor shall remove all rubbish and waste materials resulting from his work and leave the whole system in perfect working order.

41. RECORD PLANS

During the progress of the work the Contractor shall keep a record of all changes to the original plans.

Upon completion of the work the Contractor shall turn over one set of signed blueprints to the representative of the Department at the time of his inspection, with such changes clearly recorded in red. Blueprints for this purpose will be furnished by the Department.

42. GUARANTEE

The Contractor will be called upon to guarantee his work for a period of one year after date of acceptance by the owner. He shall make good or replace any defect arising in his work during that period, at his own expense and as soon as possible after having been notified in writing that such defect occurs.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Mr. Graham, Indian Commissioner, met us here on the 9th inst., and we spent the day looking over a number of farms which could be purchased, and of which nearly all were valued at about $100.00 per acre.

We made a selection, which is by all odds, the best when viewed from a three-fold stand-point, namely; location, quality of land, and price. The latter being about $70.00 per acre. I enclose you a copy of the option, which contains a description of the location of the land. You will notice that the option expires on October 15th.

On the 10th, Mr. Graham and I visited the Red Deer Institute for the purpose of inspection the buildings, and the farm.

Mr. Graham has a clear conception of the proposition, and all that it involves. He will send you his report on his return to Regina.

In the meantime, I wish to call your attention to the following facts:

1st.-That the Red Deer Institute Buildings are in a very poor condition. Nothing has been spent on them for over 15 years, beyond what was actually necessary to keep them in repair. They never were suitable, and never can be made so. There is very little value in the out-buildings, beyond the Principal's Home.

To put up proper buildings would cost at least $100,000, since the boy's building as well as that of the girl's would have to be pulled down and rebuilt. If this were done, the Institute would still be geographically in the wrong place.

2nd.-Edmonton is geographically about the centre of the constituency we wish to serve.

This constituency has in the neighborhood of 240 Protestant Indian children of school age.

3rd.-We understand that there is $60,000 available for the Methodist Church for plant. The Department has the assurance through the commission composed of Dr. Endicott and myself, that the Church is willing that this $60,000 shall be used towards making the change from Red Deer to Edmonton.

This amount will purchase the land in question.

over.
Mr. D. C. Scott,

4th.-The Red Deer farm, consists of 1,120 acres of land, of which, 480 acres is first class agricultural land, and 640 acres is fine pasture and is used for such. This land can be easily sold, already enquiries are being made. The proceeds of the sale of the 1,500 acres of ranching land at Morley, will go a long way towards putting up the necessary buildings.

5th.-The Red Deer Institute is closed, waiting a decision on this question. The option runs out on the purchase of land selected, October 15th., which requires that a decision must be made without delay.

The general board of Missions of the Methodist Church, meet during the first week in October.

If you will give this your immediate and favorable consideration, and inform me at Toronto, before the 7th of October, you will greatly oblige.

Yours sincerely,

In accordance with your wishes expressed in letter of the 6th of August, I went to Edmonton on the 10th of the present month and met there the Rev. Ferrier, Rev. Woodward and Rev. Bannier who comprised a Board representing the Methodist Church, for the purpose of dealing with the matter of selecting a site for a new Boarding School to replace the one now situated four miles from the town of Red Deer.

In company with the above named Gentleman I visited three locations, two of which appeared to me as being very desirable sites for a school, but the one that appealed to me most was about 85 acres, which can be purchased for $70.00 per acre, a total of $60,000.00. It is situated on the Sturgeon River, eight miles from Edmonton; the soil is a rich black loam and judging from the grain stocks on this land and the adjoining farms, I can safely say the land is of the very best for grain raising. Part of this land is facing the Sturgeon River, which means a great deal when raising stock, which all Indian schools should do. I am told that water in wells is easily obtained; in fact there are two good wells now on the land. Situated on this land are several farm buildings amongst which are two fairly good dwellings which could be moved if necessary, to the site on which the school buildings will be erected. There is a considerable portion of this land covered with light scrub and poplar bluffs; this can be easily cleared off and the result would be the finest land imaginable. Of course there is a proportion of this land already under cultivation and the paved streets of the City of Edmonton come within four miles, which means a great deal.

I did not visit any of the Reserves in the district for the purpose of looking into the matter of pupils for a school, should one be established, as I was familiar with conditions.

D.S. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I visited the Red Deer Industrial School, in company with the above named Gentlemen. Here I saw a very fine farm of 480 acres, 400 of which were under cultivation. Some of the standing grain was as good as any I had seen anywhere this year. There is also a good section of farming land owned by the Government. The two main buildings of this School are simply unfit for habitation. It is difficult for me to go into full details, but I shall however mention a few. The floors are completely gone in most rooms; the walls and ceilings require complete renewing; the doors are all more or less broken; the windows are in bad shape. The building was poorly laid out in the first place, and from what I could find out it has been with difficulty that the work has been carried on for the past fifteen years.

I am satisfied that if the Red Deer property is disposed of little or nothing will be obtained for the two main buildings, as they are worthless as they stand today. The only thing that could be done with them is to tear them down and save what material there is in them to reconstruct other buildings. The outside walls are the only part of them that is of any value whatever. I understand that nothing has been spent on these buildings for the last fifteen years, excepting what was actually necessary. In my opinion it would be economy to erect new buildings rather than to put the present ones in shape, so that they could be classed as up-to-date. In fact I doubt if this could be done, for as I said, we have only got the outside walls that are of any value whatever.

The principal's dwelling and two other small houses are not in bad shape, but this is all there is in the way of buildings that are of any value.

I understand this property would readily sell for $55.00 to $60.00 per acre and that the Department have 15,000 acres set aside at Morley for school purposes that could be sold for $15.00 per acre. It seems to me the question of financing a new School for Edmonton could be easily arranged.

There is no doubt in my mind that Edmonton is the proper place for an Indian Industrial School and not Red Deer.

MEMORANDUM

Hon. Mr. Meighen -

I beg to submit herewith a report received from Commissioner Graham dated 19th September on the project of removing the industrial school conducted by the Methodist Church at present located at Red Deer to a location to be chosen at Edmonton. In this connection I would refer you to my memorandum of July 25th last and to my letter to Commissioner Graham of August 6th. In the letter you will note that I followed your directions and informed Mr. Graham you were not disposed to favour the project at present. Notwithstanding that fact Mr. Graham has reported in favour of the change.

He condemns unreservedly the buildings at Red Deer and says they are simply unfit for habitation. He states that there is no doubt in his mind that Edmonton is the proper place for an industrial school and not Red Deer, and he finds the property which had been selected by the Church authorities, and upon which they have an option, is admirably adapted for the purposes of the school.

I am now pleased to recommend that the change take place in the interests of this institution, and would propose to purchase the property from funds provided by Parliament for the educational work of the Methodist Church among the Indians. It will probably cost us $70,000.00 to erect a new building, but as against the total outlay, both for land and buildings, we have assets that will be worth at least $60,000.00. We own 1500 acres near the Stony Reserve, Morley for which we have been offered $15.00 an acre, and we ought to get at least $40,000.00 out of the Red Deer property. I would like your authority to investigate the title to this property and proceed with its purchase if that is satisfactory. The option expires on the 13th inst.

Deputy Superintendent-General.

Dear Sir:

This purchase has been completed and the title for the lands now stands in the name of His Majesty the King as represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs. We therefore enclose you herewith abstracts of title covering the lands in question showing the property now to be registered as indicated aforesaid, subject only to the mortgage to the National Trust Co., Ltd. You will notice that the abstract shows the mortgage at the original amount, namely, $18,000.00. We have paid the National Trust Co. the payment of principal and interest which matured on January 1st, amounting to $2365.00 and we enclose herewith the Trust Company's receipt for this amount. This leaves the mortgage standing as on the 1st January, 1920, at $16,000.00. We also enclose receipts for taxes for the current year, all taxes on the property being paid in full to December 31st, 1919.

As was pointed out to you by the writer, the Department were to pay to Mr. Hume interest on his equity
Duncan C. Scott, Esq.  
Jan. 23/20

in this farm from the date of the expiration of the option until the actual date of payment. Your remittance covered interest only up to December 15th; there is consequently interest from December 15th to December 29th on the sum of $41,926.90, being Mr. Hume's equity, this interest amounting to $128.80. You will remember also the writer discussed with you the matter of fire insurance premium. There is an unearned premium on these policies which should be paid to Mr. Hume amounting to $40.00. The Department would therefore owe Mr. Hume the further sum of $168.80 on these adjustments.

You remitted to us to cover the payment of interest and principal on the mortgage, the sum of $2500.00; we disbursed from this sum, $2365.00, leaving a balance of $135.00 in hand, so that if the Department will remit to us the difference between $168.80 and $135., which we have on hand, or the net sum of $33.80, this will cover the adjustments with Mr. Hume.

If you desire a complete description of these lands, as shown upon the title, we will be pleased to have same prepared and forwarded to you. In the meantime you are no doubt aware that the Duplicate Certificate of Title to the property, although issued in the name of His Majesty the King, as above set forth, will according to the Land Titles Act of this Province, remain in the Registrar's Office until the mortgage is discharged.

From the aforementioned communications, it would appear that the mining rights under this area are not available. It is not apparent to me whether this is a ruling generally applied to all lands held by the Department for Industrial School purposes, or whether this particular case has been considered on its merits.

I am venturing to set forth conditions which would arise if a lease were granted and the mineral worked in the hopes that you will bring the matter up for special consideration by this Department.

1. It is believed that a coal seam 12 feet thick underlies the area at a depth of 147 feet.

2. Such a seam economically worked would produce 8,600 tons of merchantable coal per acre, yielding at the Royalty exacted exacted by the Department of the Interior, viz: 5¢ per ton, $432.00 per acre.

3. Systematic working of such a seam would not result in spoiling the surface for agricultural purposes by the causing of breaks or holes due to subsidence, but would result in the lowering of the surface without breaking.

4. Any buildings proposed, or existing, can be protected against any subsidence by the leaving of pillars in their vicinity.

5. Should the Department see its way to granting me a lease, I am prepared to undertake the following, in addition to paying Royalty:
(a) A payment of the market value per acre of the surface considered as farm land, for each acre under which coal is mined as and when such occurs.

(b) Should any holes occur as the result of mine workings, a payment per acre so damaged of four times the value of the surface as farm lands.

(c) Should any scholars of the Industrial School desire instruction in mining, etc., to employ same at the regular wage obtaining in the Edmonton Field.

From the foregoing it may be seen that owing to its peculiar situation this School may become more than self-supporting, in fact make sufficient out of the mineral to equip it in any manner desirable without prejudice to the site.

I shall esteem it a favor if you will be good enough to consider these points at your leisure and communicate further with me.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

James A. Church.

Dear Sir:

My attention has been drawn to the fact that we do not own the mineral rights upon the main section of our property. Under an old right the mineral rights go with the title on the river lot and also the quarter, but this law does not hold for the main section. The other day I heard a rumor that coal mining operations were to be commenced at Campbell, which is where we are located. Now the well log gives us an eleven foot seam of coal at a depth of 135 feet, and it is possible that mining operations would be profitable for us at some future date. I would suggest that the Department protect its interests in this matter and if possible take steps to secure the mineral rights on this property. I am not very thoroughly acquainted with law in this matter and it is possible that being owned by the crown carries its own rights. This however will draw your attention to the matter. I would also suggest that you take the coal mining proposition up with Mr. Graham and Mr. Ferrier when they are in Ottawa.

Yours Truly,

Dear Sir:

Referring to your File No. 522194-22 of March 5, 1921,
I drilled a well at the Indian Industrial School at Edmonton
last Summer and finished up in September or first of October
in 1920, which your Representative of the School Mr. J.F. Woodsworth
accepted the work.

The well was drilled to the depth of 525 feet deep and tested for quantity of water at the rate of 45 Gal.
per minute, for seventy-eight hours.

And at the time I didn't know but what your Department was satisfied with it, and the Industrial School
of Indian Affairs moved my machinery away from the drilling site
and agreed to settle soon, and he kept putting me off all the
time telling me that the Department was slow in forwarding the
settlement, and what do you think of the whole thing do you
end to settle soon or not. I told Mr. J.F. Woodsworth that I
would clean out the well to where the casing went bad to
get the supply of water if they would move my machinery back
and away and furnish beef and oil with out charge to the
Department, if they would settle.

In going so deep there the casing was not heavy enough
to stand the pressure of heaving Quick Sands and caving earths
and the casing busted and I worked two months getting it out.

Your Truly,

Instructions for Using Alberta Bituminous or Tar Sands

FOR SIDEWALKS, STABLES, FLOORS, ETC.

1. The Bituminous Sands should be heated to about 300 degrees and mixed with an equal amount of gravel and sand or crushed stone. The proper heat can be easily determined. At first, the mass is sticky, but when it spreads easily like soft mortar, it is ready for use.

2. The heating can be done on a ¼” or ⅜” iron sheet by raising it about one foot off the ground and building a wood fire under it.

3. The gravel and sand or crushed stone should be spread on the plate and the tar sands piled on top. As the mass becomes heated, it should be turned with a shovel the same as concrete.

4. Care should be taken not to over-heat the tar sand or let it take fire.

5. An old consolidated cinder or gravel walk is an ideal base on which to spread the tar sands.

6. For light traffic sidewalks, cellar floors, etc., the mixture should be spread about ½” thick, raked even and then rolled with a 250 to 300 pound iron roller. This will leave the wearing surface ¼” thick. For heavy traffic sidewalks, stable floors, etc., the wearing surface should be spread about 2” thick.

7. For mixing a small quantity of the material, an old steel scraper could be used for the heating.

8. Farmers will find the Tar Sands excellent for floors of horse and cow stalls and granary floors. Mice and rats will not eat through it, and the alkali soils or the ammonia of stables do not injure it as they do concrete.

9. It can be patched easily, or broken up, heated and re-laid. This Alberta Natural Resource is, by its elasticity and resistance of chemical action, especially suited to Alberta soils and climate.

10. We also manufacture a Tar Sand heated and mixed by which the tar sands and gravel or crushed stone are mixed hot and can be laid cold.
