Legislators Inspect Tar-Sand Deposits

ALBERTA SOLONS ARE IMPRESSED WITH UNDEVELOPED WEALTH

Sufficient asphalt sand lies in Athabasca district to pave every road in Canada, geologist says.

Scientists endeavor to place development on paying basis.

MEMBERS of the Legislative Assembly of Alberta have completed an inspection tour through the tar-sand districts of the far-northern section of that province. The trip was made over the Alberta and Great Waterways line as far as the town of Waterways, where the legislators were deeply impressed by the possibilities for developing the oil district after viewing several experimental stations in operation where efforts are being made to add to Canada's crude oil supply and to develop cheap and dependable asphalt for good roads throughout Canada, particularly for the prairie provinces.

The raw materials with which experiments have been carried on are the famous Athabasca tar-sands—that undefined but assuredly immense deposit of petroleum-impregnated sandstone lying for hundreds of miles along the Athabasca River and its tributaries.

Owing to the difficulties of exploration through a muskeg country, the extent of these tar sand deposits has never been accurately determined. There are indications, however, that the tar sand area extends over 400 miles from east to west; while from north to south there are outcroppings for a distance of 150 miles.

It is claimed that in the Athabasca district there is sufficient asphalt sand to pave every highway in Canada and to leave a great deal of the material for export. It is further stated, on no less an authority than the word of Dr. J. O. Hosworth, the British petroleum geologist, that the crude oil content of the tar sand deposits, if it could be extracted on a commercial basis, would be sufficient to meet the world's needs for at least 200 years, at the present rate of consumption.

There has always been, however, the apparently insurmountable difficulty of getting the crude oil out of the tar sands.

Was Once Huge Oil Field

The Athabasca district is not a normal oil field, despite the vast amount of oil it still contains. It consists of a fault that it was once a huge oil field; but that by some means—glacial erosion, probably, in the great ice age that once prevailed over most of Canada—the large rock covering the oil deposits was scraped away, and now lies, leaving the oil sands themselves exposed. In the thousands of years since then, the lighter constituents of the crude oil have evaporated, leaving an impure bed of sandstone saturated with bituminous asphalt oil.

For many years efforts have been made to develop the tar sand deposits. First, oil operators tried drilling, as in any other oil field; but though oil was met at comparatively shallow depths, the oil which was heavy and viscous. Later, a great many experimenters worked on processes for separating the crude oil from the bituminous sand, or for separating both the oil and bitumen from the sand.

Many of these processes were scientifically workable. That is, they succeeded in extracting the crude oil, or the asphalt, as the case might be. The difficulty was that they were too expensive to operate on a commercial scale. The finished product which was got than it was worth.

A couple of years ago, Thomas Draper, of Petrolia, Ont., came forward as a practical oil man and a manufacturer of asphalt. He had a relatively small plant producing asphalt from the tar sands, and he started a larger plant, which was successful at Edmonton, Alta., and Great Waterways, and Great Waterways district with the result that he was interested in the development of the Athabasca district.

In 1922, extracts were made from the tar sands at Edmonton, and a small plant was also installed at Great Waterways, and Great Waterways district with the result that he was interested in the development of the Athabasca district.

The cost of mining the tar sand and transporting it to the extraction plant; and it may be said that the plant is now operating on something approaching a commercial scale, though it is still necessary to develop a market for the output.

Process In Operation

In the plant at Waterways, two processes can be operated. One of these separates the oils from the other material; the other extracts the asphaltum. By the first named process, when the bitumen gravity is obtained, yielding 5 per cent, gasoline, 3.25 per cent, kerosene, 2.5 per cent, light gas oil, 15.625 per cent, medium gas oil, 43.75 per cent, lubricating oil and 20 per cent, refined asphalt. There is a small amount of wax, a trifle over 1 per cent.

Owing to the small percentage of the lighter constituents and the presence of sulphur, the crude oil is not the most satisfactory for producing gasoline or kerosene; but the bitumen oil stands an excellent chance to be an excellent product for use in cold climates. It does not congeal at 20 below zero.

The asphaltum process gives a much larger yield of merchantable product, ranging from 15 to 25 per cent, of the raw tar sand. It is to all intents and purposes similar to the Trinidad asphalt, which, with that of California, is now imported into Canada in large quantities. Incidentally, though there are other known sources of asphalt in Canada, the Athabasca deposits contain more asphalt than the Trinidad and California deposits combined.

Naturally, if an abundance of cheap asphalt can be produced in Alberta, that fact will mean a lot for road building programs, at least in the northern part of the province; and if satisfactory freight rates can be secured, the Athabasca product should ultimately displace the imported asphalt throughout the Dominion.

Sand Coated With Asphalt

However, besides these possibilities, there is a likelihood of utilizing the tar sands in their natural state for road making. Every grain of sandstone is coated with an asphalt film which cannot be deducted by any mechanical mix. For thousands of years, the asphalts oils have been soaking into the sandstone deposits of northern Alberta; and while exploration and seepage have taken off the lighter constituents of the oil, the asphalt has coated every grain of sand.

In the laying of asphalt pavements, the refined asphalt is heated and mixed with sand and gravel in certain proportions by mechanical means; but in the tar sand deposits the work has been already done by nature; and all that is necessary is to heat the tar sand and roll it.

Experimental pavements constructed of the raw tar sand, thus treated, have been laid at Edmonton, as well as pavements of asphalt and other materials in various proportions. It is hoped in this way to find out the best method of utilizing the tar sands.

Of course even a bulky product such as the raw tar sand, after a certain distance freight rates would become prohibitive. But within the low freight rate zone it is believed the raw tar sands will be the favorite material for paving, while at a greater distance Athabasca is prepared to supply refined asphalt. Both methods not merely help to solve the good roads problem but develop an important, valuable, but heretofore neglected asset of the Dominion.

Tar sand development work is yet in its infancy. The hills all along the river carry millions of dollars worth of potential wealth in tar sands. With the oil-fields of the world being drained daily to meet the ever-growing demand for more and still more oil, there must some day be created a demand for all the oil which some hitherto unsolved commercial process will eventually secure from those hills of unmounted wealth.
The Relation of Alberta Tar Sands to Modern Road Construction

Alberta Bituminous Sands for Rural Roads

Nature has mixed the bituminous binder of the Alberta Tar Sands in a manner which it is practically impossible to duplicate mechanically, and each grain of sand has been impregnated with the bitumen by Nature's hand. Nature works surely, slowly and with definite purpose, and when working in this case did its work uniformly. However, while each and every grain has been impregnated with a film of asphaltum, it is necessary to add more sand or gravel to the mixture when using, according to the type of work being done, but the tar sands in their natural state can be handled and mixed in as small or as large a quantity as is required.

Hitherto, the chief research work in connection with these sands has been along the line of extracting the bituminous content, and adapting the same to commercial purposes. No real experiments as to the value of the tar sands in the raw state for road surfacing have been entered into, with the exception of an experiment made in 1915, when a small piece of pavement was laid of this material on Kinnaird St. in Edmonton, and this experimental piece of pavement, although subjected to heavy traffic, has stood up well and is still in excellent condition.

The Kinnaird Street Experiment

Here, pavement made of raw Alberta Tar Sands, to which the proper admixture of sand and gravel was added, was laid down in 1915. Today, despite years of traffic, some eight years in all, that pavement is just as good as when it was laid. It has stood the test of traffic, the test of weather, the test of climatic extremes, of frost, snow and summer heat, and is as good today as the day it was laid.

Therefore, it can safely be assumed that these tar sands are adaptable for road use in their raw state, if the cost of transportation of the same from the bed to the road can be overcome along commercial lines.

Value of Tar Sands in Road Construction

This article deals with the question of using the raw tar sands as a binding material for the rural roads and main highways of Alberta, and it is from this point of view that their use is being suggested and discussed. Experiments are at the present time being conducted to extract the asphaltum content on commercial lines, but when the following information, facts and figures concerning the commercial use of these sands is digested, it will be readily seen that the most feasible line along which these sands can be quickly adapted for use commercially, is along the line of road surfacing. It is true that there are no other known sources of asphaltum in Canada outside of this deposit, and that in consequence millions of tons of asphaltum are imported each year from Trinidad and California, this notwithstanding the fact that we have, in the hills of Northern Alberta, more asphalt than the combined resources of Trinidad and California. When the process of extraction of both asphaltum and oils from these enormous deposits is more fully developed, it will be a straight manufacturing proposition, and it is to be hoped that the day is not far distant when the development of methods of extraction will serve to bring the production of asphaltum and oils on as sure a basis as wheat or steel, but until that day arrives, the most logical use to which the tar sands of Northern Alberta can be put to, is the surfacing of roads with the raw or treated sands, to which other sand or stone has been added to make the proper spreading content.

The Exhibition Experiments

Through Mr. Thos. Drayton, Manager of the McMurray Asphaltum and Oils Limited, who are developing these sands for their oil content at the present time and are emphatic as to the
fact their interests lie more in this direction than in the use of the raw tar sands for road surfacing, it has been possible to make further experiments in connection with road surfacing with these tar sands. During each day of the Exhibition, pieces of road were surfaced in the presence of many representative men and bodies, the whole of the laying, preparing and completion being done with the crudest of tools, and all present were convinced that these tar sands are adaptable to Alberta's road problem, as a proper surfacing material for the hard clay base that obtains in dry years.

In these experiments Mr. Draper received the co-operation of the Huff Gravel Co., Ltd., of Edmonton, who supplied the necessary gravel and sands.

These experiments were made in the following form: A sidewalk 100 feet long and twelve feet wide was laid as an approach to the Manufacturer's Building. The thickness of this sidewalk was \( \frac{3}{4} \) inches, and although there was no attempt to compete as to cost of construction with other forms of pavement, the actual cost of laying the yardage with the crudest of tools was only $1.50 per square yard. This surfacing is heavier by half an inch than the ordinary sidewalk surfacing used on city streets, and if it was laid at the lighter thickness, the cost should not exceed $1.00 per square yard, leaving a good profit for the contractor. A contractor who witnessed the experiment at the end of the week, after seeing the way this piece and other pieces had stood up under the heavy traffic of the fair crowds, especially the piece across the main road, where constant traffic of motor vehicles and heavy trucks had occurred, said, "We contractors intend to use this stuff hereafter, we are concrete men, but we simply have to use this material, because it is cheaper laid, and so to live we must use it. Already," he added, "we have some thousands of yards of sidewalks and small work to lay for various people, who have decided upon these sands for approaches to houses, and other purposes."

The Exhibition Experiments—Rolling the Tar Sands After Laying

Experiments Prove Utility

The various experiments made proved to the satisfaction of all present the fact that provided the raw tar sands could be landed on the job at a reasonable cost their use for road surfacing in Alberta was possible, and that the using of them would without a doubt improve the chances for road extension on permanent lines in Alberta. These experiments were witnessed by Lt. Governor Brett, Hon. H. Greenfield, Premier of Alberta; Hon. Chas. Stewart, Minister of the Interior; Hon. Alex Ross, Minister of Highways; Hon. Vernon Smith, Minister of Railways; J. A. Dalrymple, Vice-Pres. C. N. R.; A. E. Warren, Gen. Manager Western Lines; D. C. Coleman, Vice-Pres. Canadian Pacific Rly.; Geo. Stevens, Freight Traffic...
in the ordinary way asphalt is mixed with other ingredients, mostly sand, it would therefore appear that there would be no saving in extracting the asphaltum and shipping that in preference to shipping the sands in the raw state, for, as previously stated, in the latter case the sands have been thoroughly impregnated by Nature with the asphaltum content in a manner it is impossible to do by mechanical means, in fact, it seems as if Nature has given us a perfect road surface mixture. This mixing of the raw material with the necessary amount of more sand, clay or gravel is governed entirely by the class of work required.

Cost of Transportation

Transportation from the fields at McMurray by rail over the Alberta and Great Waterways Railway, a Government owned line, to Edmonton is the main feature that enters into the commercial use of these sands.

As the refined products, if used for road building and pavement, would have to be mixed

An Important Feature

Present indications point to the fact that tar sands will enter largely into the construction of the permanent roads of Alberta in the future, and it may, therefore, be wise to discuss the conditions under which such should be laid down to get the best results. The first and most important feature that must be considered is drainage, which applies equally to roads no matter what material is used in construction. Local materials can always be used as foundation for tar sand surfacing, even clay, which abounds all over Alberta may be used as
a mixture if dried and ground, which can be done on the spot where it is excavated while the road is being built.

The drying and grinding of clay is an easy matter in Alberta where in nearly every part either seams of coal or wood abound for fuel.

Wherever there is gravel no difficulty is anticipated in using tar sands, as the experiments at the Exhibition, where roads and side walks which were thoroughly tested afterwards by traffic, were laid on practically no foundation at all except the natural flooring, proved its utility.

Results of Actual Tar Sand Road Construction in the United States

The Kentucky Rock Asphalt Company, of Louisville, Ky., have been using the low grade asphalt rock (tar sands) for many years in the surfacing of roads. It has been used in its raw state and the quality has been of a much lower grade than that of the Northern Alberta material, and, unlike Alberta sands, it will not stand mixing with other aggregates.

All of the railways in the district in which this material is used issue special low freight tariff rates covering the movement of this material, and it has been transported for use in its raw state, as far as 750 miles from the source of production. The railway company quote rates on this material to the following States: Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, North Carolina, South Carolina, Ohio, Tennessee, Virginia, and West Virginia.

Its Use on United States Highways

Parts of the Lincoln National Highway, the Dixie National Highway and many other of the leading trunk roads in the Central and Southern States are surfaced with this material and practically in every case the best wearing satisfaction in the carrying of the enormous traffic these highways are subjected to, has been obtained.

Conclusion

The vast quantities of raw material lying within rail distance of practically every part of Alberta, its cheapness delivered on the job, its durability as a surface covering, the ease and economy with which it can be handled, and the fact that successful experiments and tests have proved its adaptability, although made with the crudest of tools and under conditions just as crude, appears to prove that Alberta has all the material within the Province for road building, and careful further consideration will without a doubt be given to its commercial use.

I suggest that the present situation be carefully studied in order to ascertain whether it is necessary, from a departmental standpoint, to retain such a large area for the use of the school and that in the meantime the Principal be informed, if it is considered advisable to lease any portion of the school lands, it must be done by a formal lease from the Superintendent General - in which case the lessee would be liable to be assessed and taxed by the municipality in respect of his interest in the said lands during the term of the lease.

Under the Consolidated Revenue and Audit Act, it would be necessary that the rental obtained from lease of government land be forwarded for deposit to the credit of the Receiver General. No refund could be made and the school would not financially benefit. If the Principal, in the interest of the school, requires to utilize the full quantity of land for farming purposes, he should engage sufficient help to farm all the land. If any portion is not required and cannot be utilized by the school staff themselves, the portion not so required could be sold.

I should be glad to receive your direction in the matter.

Encl.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 403-11A-H, also to date of the 26th ultimo regarding the leasing of some school land by Mr. Woodsworth, Principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School. I was in Edmonton last week, and while there went out to the school and discussed this matter thoroughly with the Principal.

I advised Mr. Woodsworth that this land had been leased contrary to the regulations of the Department and that the lease would have to be cancelled or the Department would take over the land, and either lease it or sell it. The Principal at first resented this attitude, and advised me that he was going to wire to the Church authorities in Toronto, which I informed him he was quite at liberty to do. What the Principal really dreaded was to face the lessees, as the arrangements made with the two neighbouring farmers called for a 3-year lease, and it had only run one year, and he was afraid they would demand some recompense. One thing I made clear to the Principal was that if the land was required it would have to be worked by the school and not by any of the neighbouring farmers; and I quite agree with him that to take care of their feed requirements, etc., the land is actually required by the school. I see no reason why it could not be handled by that institution without any lease.

Mr. Woodsworth finally asked me if I would assist him in settling the matter with the lessees and I stated that I was quite prepared to do what I could. He sent over for the two lessees and the matter was finally settled without any difficulty whatever: The two men in question were quite reasonable and when I left, after having spent a whole day in dealing with this matter, everyone concerned seemed to be quite satisfied, and the land in question will be worked by the school. Mr. Woodsworth informed me that the lease was only a temporary arrangement as most of the boys at the school were small and not able to do much work on the farm, but it had been his intention to take the land back at the end of the three years. The amount of grain threshed on this lease last year was about 7000 bushels of wheat, oats and barley, of which 50% belonged to the school. Besides this, practically all the lessees' share of the grain was purchased by the School.

I trust we will have no more difficulty in this connection in future.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Murphy:

RE: INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
EDMONTON - CONTRACT WITH DAVIDSON
& LATIMER

I wired you today as follows:

"WOODSWORTH PRINCIPAL INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL EDMONTON
MADE WRITTEN AGREEMENT THREE YEARS FROM APRIL EIGHTEENTH
THIRTY FOUR WITH TWO FARMERS TO WORK THREE HUNDRED ACRES
SCHOOL LANDS ON TERMS STOP ON EIGHTEENTH CHRISTIANSON
NOTIFIED THEM VACATE CLAIMING WOODSWORTH UNAUTHORIZED MEN
CANNOT MAKE OTHER ARRANGEMENTS NOW URGE CONTINUANCE CON-
TRACT THIS YEAR WRITING"

I have before me the typed original agreement,
dated April 14th, 1934, regarding the cropping and cultivation
of the lands of the above school being Section 12, Twp. 54,
Rge. 25, W4th. The agreement is signed on the 18th April,
1934 by J. F. Woodsworth and the two farmers in question and is
witnessed. It is expressed as being "to maintain and hold
good from the 18th day of April 1934 to the 18th day of
April 1937." Under its terms the two parties of the second
part (Davidson and Latimer) agreed to cultivate the lands accord-
ing to three carefully drawn maps or plans, one for each year,
in which the fields are plotted out and each field marked with
the acreage and crop and how it is to be treated. The culti-
vated land in all is about 320 acres but there was a proviso
enabling Mr. Woodsworth to withdraw and occupy and work himself
or by the available labour of the school, small parcels amount-
ing one year to 40 acres and another year to 30 acres; but
last year only about 15 acres of land was withdrawn and worked by
the school, so that you may say the agreement covered 300 acres
of cultivated land. The parties of the second part were to supply
one-half of the twine for harvesting the grain and the green-feed
and pay one-half of the threshing expenses computed on the bushel-
age threshed and the current rates, the reason for this being that
the school owned the threshing outfit, separate and tractor, and
stipulated that the expenses of the threshing should be the regular
threshing charges and not the mere out-of-pocket expenses. The
parties of the second part were to do all the work, including
cutting, stocking and stacking as well as putting the crop in and
keeping it free from weeds, etc., etc., and were to receive one-half
of the green-feed and threshed grain. The school was to supply all
the seed-grain & one-half of the twine used in the harvest operat-
ions for grain and green-feed and was to receive one-half of all
green-feed and threshed grain. The school was also to receive two-
thirds of all straw and the parties of the second part the remaining
one-third. This is the essence of the agreement except that there
is a final clause that the parties are entering upon it with good
will and with the idea of mutual cooperation.

The facts as I have them are that the school not
having a sufficient number of large boys to work the farm in 1934,
Mr. Woodsworth got in touch with Davidson and Latimer or with one
of them, and himself put the proposition up to them. They did not
seek it. I understand they worked the lands very carefully and
faithfully last year; but as a result of the frost the proceeds
gave them little better than very poor wages if it gave them that
much. They were counting on making any profit from the operations
of this land this year and next.

On the 18th of this month, that is the very day on
which the second year commenced, Mr. Christianson saw them and
told them they would have to vacate the lands as Mr. Woodsworth
had no authority to enter into the agreement and that the agree-
ment was therefore null and void. They accordingly consulted me.
Latimer is the son of a very old client of my firm, very respect-
able people, and Davidson seems to be an equally respectable and
reliable man. It is extremely hard on them now to take the stand
that Woodsworth was without authority. Surely the situation might
have been known and should have been known long ago, some time
last year, and reasonable notice given to them even assuming that
Woodsworth had no authority and that the contract is void.

In that event and assuming that the Department did
nothing which would have the effect of holding out Woodsworth
as its agent, Davidson and Latimer would have an action against
Woodsworth and possibly against the school authorities; but they do
not wish to take this course and I certainly shall not advise them to. Under the circumstances, however, would it not be possible to let the contract run this year at least, even if it is not allowed to run its whole term. As time is pressing I should be glad if you could give the matter immediate consideration and wire me the result. Meantime I have advised the two men that they should not be asked to take Mr. Christianson's mere word that the contract is null and void. That is a question of law depending on all the facts and neither I nor they yet have anything like all the facts.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) A---- U. G. Bury

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

I have your memorandum of the 30th ultimo, with accompanying letter from Mr. A. U. G. Bury, L.I., concerning the leasing by the Principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School, of 275 acres of the school lands. In this connection I would refer to my memoranda of February 26th, March 9th and April 29th last. This land, the property of the Crown, was leased by the Principal, Rev. J. F. Woodsworth, without referring the matter to the Department or receiving any authority. No copy of the lease has been received, but the Department has been informed by Mr. G. C. Laight, the local Indian agent, of the terms of the lease, as follows:

"On April 1st, 1934, Mr. Woodsworth drew up an agreement with Mr. William Davidson and Mr. Alfred Latimer, of Edmonton, to rent 275 acres on a crop share basis, both of these men are farmers living near the school; the agreement with Mr. Davidson and Mr. Latimer was that the school management should have full control over the land rented, having the right to stipulate what crops should be grown each year and how much should be summer fallowed. The school management to furnish one half of all seed required, purchase one half of the binder twine and pay one half of the cost of threshing, and retain the right to buy all the grain these two men would have for sale out of their share of the crop, also all their share of the green feed, and the school to receive two thirds of the straw. The agreement also calls for the school threshing outfit to be used to thresh the grain, this being done to guard against any weed seeds being carried on the land. Mr. Woodsworth informed me that the school purchased grain and green feed to the value of approximately $1,000, being part of Mr. Davidson and Mr. Latimer's share of the crop grown on the 275 acres of school lands."

Mr. Woodsworth, the principal of the school, was entirely at fault in leasing the land. The leasing of Crown Lands must be done by formal lease from the Superintendent General, and, under the Consolidated Revenue and Audit Act, 1931, it is necessary that any rental obtained from the lease of government land be forwarded for deposit to the credit of the Receiver General.

Mr. Inspector Christiansen was instructed to proceed
proceed to the school and inquire into the matter. When the Department received his report, dated the 23rd ultimo, a copy was attached to memorandum to the Honourable the Superintendent General dated the 29th ultimo.

I would refer you to the final paragraph of Mr. Christianson's report. He states that, after discussing the matter with the two lessees, they seemed to be quite satisfied to cancel the lease.

Mr. Christianson states that all the school land is actually required for farming and grazing purposes and that, in future, it will be farmed by the school staff.

Mr. Woodsworth, having no legal authority, was not competent to execute a lease of crown land. As stated above, lease of crown lands must be executed by the Superintendent General and the proceeds accruing under such lease must be forwarded for deposit to the credit of the Receiver General. Therefore, the agreement made between the Principal and Messrs. Davidson and Latimer would appear to be null and void.

Regarding the suggestion of Mr. Bury to let the contract run during this year, I would point out that the land is necessary for school purposes and that the Principal will arrange for the cultivation of same this spring.

I am returning herewith Mr. Bury's letter.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr. Christianson:

I enclose herewith a document signed by the men David-
son and Latimer who were interested in the farming agreement of
last year. Since I saw you a fresh development has taken place:
Some days after you were here, and before we were able to get to-
gether, these two men took the matter to A.U.G.Bury, K. C., of Ed-
monton, the federal member for East Edmonton. They explained the
matter to him, gave him a copy of the agreement and had him send
it to Ottawa. He also sent a telegram to Ottawa, protesting against
the action of the Department, and trying to have them reinstated in
working the land. At first they would have nothing to do with me,
or consider a settlement such as was proposed when you were here.
They also apparently disregarded the closing of the matter which
they agreed upon, with you as witness, but were trying to open up
the whole matter again. However I told them they would not be able
to make any headway and would lose the chance of any settlement which
I was then prepared to make. They at last came to see me and I gave
them $200.00 apiece, as per statement. In consideration of all
their plans, their actual loss, and our good name in the community
I felt it better to make a settlement rather than have complica-
tions. They told Mr. Bury of their settlement and he is wiring
Ottawa to take no further action in the matter. It is just poss-
ible however that you may hear more about it from Ottawa, so thought
I would tell you about it so that you would know what was going on.
I do not like parting with $400.00 but they might have stuck for
less, and stirred up a lot of fuss, and now that the original
agreement has been set aside I think it better to be clear of
them in every way.

I may say that I have followed your suggestion and
hired a man to work the land under our direction. So things may
be much better for us in the fall than if we were complicated with
neighbours.

Things at the school are normal and we are now getting
on the land. I expect on Monday our new man will come to work.

I have written to Mr. Beaton suggesting that the com-
mission spend a day with you in Calgary. They will be with me
on May 14th.

Sincerely yours,

"J. F. WOODSWORTH."

RESOLUTION

WHEREAS, the Dominion Government has caused to be placed in the Municipal District of Ray, No. 549, Province of Alberta, an Indian Residential School and farm, and, as Crown Lands, these holdings are free from all taxation; and

WHEREAS, the only method of obtaining revenue by a Municipality is by a direct land tax, for which residents receive value pro rata to the taxes paid; and

WHEREAS, it is conceded that such an Indian School is a necessity and is doing good work but it is submitted that all residents of the Province are benefitted by same, not only the ratepayers of the Municipal District of Ray, who are at present carrying the whole load for the construction and maintenance of roads used by the above public institution; and

WHEREAS, the needs of such an institution in the line of supplies, etc., necessitate the abnormal use of roads during bad weather or otherwise, which make the upkeep of roads practically impossible; and

WHEREAS, plans, specifications and costs for the building of a gravel road about two and one-half miles long, to connect the institution to a gravel highway, have already been submitted, at considerable expense of time, to the Dept. of Indian Affairs at the request of Mr. Laight, Indian Agent, Winterburn, Alberta to the Council of the M. D. of Ray, it is submitted that some attention should be immediately given by the Government, in view of the fact that, had the Indian School been paying taxes during the time it has been in the Municipality, and at the rate paid by other resident landowners, a gravelled highway would now be an accomplished fact and paid for;

THEREFORE, be it resolved by the Municipal Council of Ray, 549, Province of Alberta, today sitting in Council, that this resolution be sent to the Minister of the Interior, the Minister of Indian Affairs, and Mr. J. Memorandum:

The Deputy Minister.

With reference to Mr. Pratt's memorandum of the 2nd of February in regard to an all-weather road from the Indian Residential School to the St. Albert Highway, I beg to advise that no consideration has been given to the question of contributing towards the construction of a road on either of the routes outlined on the attached map of the district.

Neither of the routes referred to pass through Indian Reserve land, and it has not been the policy of this branch to contribute towards such work on roads located outside Indian Reserves. Further, the construction or improvement of either of the roads would be for the benefit of white residents living along these roads.

I might add that in 1936 the Department was asked to contribute towards the construction of a road to the Indian Residential School, but a grant was not made for the aforesaid reasons.

With regard to the last paragraph of Mr. Pratt's memorandum asking to be informed if any assistance could be given, I would say that any expenditure made would have to be paid for from Parliamentary appropriation.

Dear Sir:

About a year ago I wrote to Dr. Dorey, of our Board of Home Missions, in regard to the possibility of leasing part of our farm lands. Dr. Dorey took the matter up with Mr. Hoey, and according to a letter from Dr. Dorey last January it would appear that the matter might be adjusted with the Department if terms and conditions were satisfactory. It should be explained that owing to a number of reasons it is practically impossible for the school management to operate the large acreage which is at present under school direction. We have under cultivation something like 500 acres, about 350 of this is usually under grain crops. In the past of course this has brought us in good returns and has enabled us to operate quite satisfactorily from a financial standpoint.

During the last few years however it has become increasingly difficult to carry on. In the first place the ruling of the Department in discharging the pupils at 16 years of age has seriously affected the help problem. Then Mr. Goodland, my farm instructor, who has been 43 years in the service is growing old and is unable to give the physical and nervous strength to the work as in other days. Since the war started it has been almost impossible to secure farm labor, and we have been operating on a ragged edge. This fall after harvest Mr. Smith, who has been with me for some 16 years bought a place of his own and is no longer with me, as it was we put in only a small acreage and arranged with outside parties to combine the crop. Part of the hay was put up on shares. I find it is necessary to cut down drastically in the number of hogs we raise, and in other ways we are trying to operate within the bounds of our ability. I mention these matters simply to give you a picture of our farm life. We are well fixed for the winter, plenty of feed and grain and vegetables, but you will agree that it is necessary to look to the coming spring.

During the last month I have had two requests from reliable farmers to operate the farm, or at least the east three-quarter section on shares. Only differing in detail—the proposition is that they supply all labor, equipment, seed, and responsibility, giving us one third of the crop. Such an arrangement would solve our labor problem, and still give us enough land for garden and hay.

With reference to Departmental letter No. IIO-0-9 dated December 10th, 1944, and addressed to Rev. J. F. Woodsworth, Principal, Indian Residential School, Edmonton, Alta. I beg to report that subject to the approval of the Department arrangements have been made with Mr Jack Glen Harrold, Farmer in the Edmonton District, Post Office address Box 535 Edmonton, Alta., to lease some of the land at the Edmonton Indian Residential School for a period of three years commencing on April 15th, 1944 on a one third share crop basis of all grain grown on the land. Following is an accurate description of the land it is desired to lease:

Part of Sec. 12 Tp. 54 Range 25 W., 4-Ms. comprising approximately 450.95 acres more or less.

Approximately 300 acres under cultivation, 140 acres in bush and 10 acres used for Right of Way for Railway Spur to the Namao Air Port.

It was suggested at a meeting of Rev. Mr Woodsworth, Mr Harrold and myself that the following be embodied in the lease.

1. The following shall be put in crop in 1944, approximately Seventy-five acres of wheat, One hundred acres of oats, Seventy-five acres of barley and Fifty acres of Summer Fallow done. That Fifty acres of Summer Fallow shall be done in 1945 and 1946.

2. The Party of the Second Part shall use for seed only good seed grain, free from dirt and weed seeds and properly treated with Ceresan, or otherwise treated chemically, and fertilize such crops of wheat and barley as approved methods of husbandry demand, provided that such fertilizer is obtainable.

3. The Party of the Second Part shall supply all equipment and labour required to seed and harvest the said crop, and will deliver the said share of crop to the granaries of the Party of the First Part at his own expense.

4. The Party of the Second Part shall use his best endeavour and approved methods of husbandry to prevent the growth of and to exterminate all noxious weeds, and will meet and fulfill all requirements of municipal or provincial authorities in this connection.

5. The Party of the Second Part will in each year of the said term thresh the crop as soon as conveniently possible after cutting, and will exercise proper care that the combine outfit be one that will not bring weed seeds onto the land.

6. The Party of the Second Part agrees that the Party of the First Part shall have the use of the bush land for pasture and the right to cut firewood off the bush land, the Party of the First Part agrees to keep all fences around the bush land used for pasture in good repair during the term of the lease.

Over.
The Party of the First Part shall provide all the granaries required for his one third share of all grain grown on the land each year.

For the information of the Department I wish to state that I am very much impressed with the appearance of Mr Harrold, he is about 27 years of age and married, he has a full line of equipment and has had considerable experience in farming which includes a course in agriculture at one of the Provincial Agriculture Colleges in Alberta.

It is expected that work on the land will commence within a week or two and I would respectfully ask that I be advised by Air Mail if the Department approves of this lease or not, Mr Harrold is anxious to start works as soon as it is fit to get on the land.

G. G. Laight,
Indian Agent.

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned have the honour to report:

That the United States War Department has made application for certain lands required for a railway spur line extending from the Northern Alberta Railway in Section twelve, Township fifty-four, Range twenty-five, west of the Fourth Meridian to Namao airfield in Township fifty-four, Range twenty-five west of the Fourth Meridian, Province of Alberta.

That the said spur line is considered to be necessary for the purposes of defence projects.

That Order in Council P.C. 6698 dated 7th September, 1943 provides that properties required by the Government of the United States for defence projects shall be acquired by the Department of Transport.

That a portion of the right of way required for the said spur line affects lands of the Edmonton Indian residential school which are under the jurisdiction of the Department of Mines and Resources.

That compensation in the amount of fourteen hundred and seventy-five dollars for the land and damages to the land of the Indian residential school has been agreed upon by the Department of Transport and the Department of Mines and Resources.

The undersigned therefore recommend that the land of the Edmonton Indian residential school required for the said right of way, as hereinafter described be and is hereby transferred to His Majesty in the right of Canada as represented by the Minister of Transport under the provisions of section 4 of The Public Lands Grants Act, Chapter 114 R.S.C. 1927.

PREVALENT ON THE UNDER DESCRIBED FARM:

During the year 1945, the following crops were grown:
Field 1-5: Oats.
Field 2: Summerfallow.
Field 3: Wheat.
Field 4: Barley (seeded to Fall Rye.)

The recommended Rotation contains 1 Summerfallow
and three Cleaning Crops, as follows:
Summerfallow.
Olli Barley fertilized.
Fall Rye.
Fall Rye.

Here is an outline of the Rotation in detail:

1946
Field 1- Summerfallow.
Field 2- Olli Barley seeded early, fertilized and seeded to P. Rye.
Field 3- Green Feed cut early, tilled, cultivated, seeded to P. Rye.
Field 4- Fall Rye.
Field 5-6- Summerfallow.
Continued.

1947
Field No:
1- Olli Barley seeded to Fall Rye.
2-3 Fall Rye.
4- Summerfallow.
5-6 Olli Barley seeded to Fall Rye.

1948
1- Fall Rye.
2-3 Summerfallow.
4- Olli Barley seeded to Fall Rye.
5-6 Fall Rye seeded back to Fall Rye.

1949
1- Summerfallow.
2-3 Olli Barley seeded to Fall Rye.
4- Fall Rye seeded back to Fall Rye.
5-6 Fall Rye.

1950
1- Olli Barley seeded to Fall Rye.
2-3 Fall Rye.
4- Fall Rye.
5-6 Summerfallow.

In other words, we could explain the rotation this way:

| Field No | 1946 | 1947 | 1948 | 1949 | 1950 |
|---------|------|------|------|------|------|
| 1       | Fallow | Barley | F. Rye. | Fallow | Barley. |
| 2-3     | Barley | G.O.F. | F. Rye. | Fallow | Barley. |
| 4       | F. Rye. | Fallow | Barley | F. Rye. | Fall Rye |
| 5-6     | Fallow | Barley | F. Rye | F. Rye | Fallow |

Thus making the following acreage in fallow and different crops each year:

✓ 1946: Fallow-154 acres; Rye-30 acres; Barley-37 acres; G. Feed-45

✓ 1948: n 82 n ; n 154 n ; n 80 n ;

✓ 1949: n 67 n ; n 167 n ; n 82 n ;

✓ 1950: n 87 n ; n 162 n ; n 67 n ;

Dear Mr. Ellett:

In reply to your letter of recent date, pertaining to the above, I must, first of all, highly compliment you on the way you are fulfilling your duties as a public servant. You realize the magnitude of the task confronting you; as a devoted and conscientious worker, you have at heart the success of your undertakings.

I take this opportunity to express my admiration for your employer: the Municipal Council of Morinville #91, which is composed of men who willingly accept their great responsibility of administering the Agricultural Problems of their Municipality as men who have a long time view of our agriculture wishing to make every ratepayer a responsible and reliable farmer.

Indeed, I am very pleased to assist you, to the best of my ability, and submit to you a Crop Rotation which should, when completed, eradicate the class "A" noxious weeds at present prevalent on the above mentioned farm thereby making it unproductive and a public menace.

Useless to say that when pollution exists as in the present case, to be effective, drastic measures have to be used. My work would have been more pleasant had I to deal with a clean farm and recommend a Rotation to keep same productive.
Mr. W. Ellett,

You may rest assured that I have given lot of thought to the present problem and kept in mind the interest of both; the owner and the renter before drafting the enclosed plan and making any recommendations.

In order to have as much uniformity as possible in the size of the fields, for economy and efficiency of operation, also to clean the farm as quickly as possible, I have taken the liberty of combining the following fields: No. 4 & 3, 5 & 6. Therefore, these fields should ultimately be dealt with as one respectively. I wish to bring to your attention the only difference of 20 acres between the smallest and largest field on the farm.

I am recommending a four year rotation as described and explained in the enclosed Plan, i.e.: summerfallow, early barley, fall rye, fall rye.

It is rather unfortunate that the whole farm has been neglected to the extent that no crop can be allowed to mature during the year 1946 except the field #2 which was summerfallowed in 1945 and field #4 seeded down to Fall Rye this fall according to our earlier recommendations.

To assist the Institution in having enough feed for their livestock, we thought it advisable to grow green feed in field #3. After said green feed has been harvested, about Aug. 1st., the land should be tilled and cultivated twice at regular intervals, and seeded down to Fall Rye on or about Sept. 1st. along with field #2 which should receive the same preparation as field #3 after the Olli barley has been taken off.

I understand that an arrangement can be made between the Institution and the renter for the purchase of the green feed.
Due to the degree of infestation, field #1, 5 and 6 must be well summer-fallowed in 1946. They should be first tilled and then cultivated every 12 to 14 days from July 10th or 15th till freeze-up. This means that the 154 acres contained in the 3 fields mentioned above must be thoroughly worked about 10 times mostly during the harvest season.

Enclosed is a letter of approbation of this Crop Rotation from Mr. Mather, our Provincial Weed Supervisor.

I really hope that the programme herewith outlined will be put to practice and trust that expected results will reward your efforts. It should be used as a demonstration to other farmers who might doubt of the possibility of totally eradicating Canada and Sow Thistles when polluting the land as in the present case.

The above described land is that portion of the farmland of the Edmonton Residential School, which was leased in 1944 to Mr. J. Harrold on a crop share basis.

I understand that the reason for granting this lease was that the school was not in a position to properly farm the land, on account of the scarcity of help, in order that the land be kept in a proper state of cultivation until such time as the school could resume operation of the farm.

The idea may have been all right, but it has not worked out in the way it was intended and the land has become so badly infested with weeds that the provincial Government authorities have stepped in, demanding a cleanup.

Just a year ago, when I went over the place for the first time with Mr. Heathcote & Mr. Woodsworth, I remarked on the slowness with which the place was being handled, and said that I thought the place was being ruined rather than farmed. At that time there was a small piece of land which was badly grown to weeds, which was described to me as that year's sunflower. To the best of my knowledge that piece of land was never touched again until this spring, when a tiller combine was put onto it and it was seeded down along with all the other acreage which had been in crop in 1944, with the exception of 37 acres which have been underflowed this year.

I am enclosing copies of correspondence, dealing with the matter, also a copy of a plan of crop rotation and summer fallow which has been drawn up by the District Agriculturalist which would take five years to carry out and which presupposes the cultivation of the land by the present lessee, of which I would not be in favor. The plan itself is all right, but it would have to be carried out strictly. In the letter I am attaching that Mr. Harrold is not the man for the job.

To be in with the 10 acres which were seeded to barley this year and which he was told to sow with a combine at the beginning of August, then to burn off the stubble to kill the weed seeds, the land was then to be sowed and worked down then seeded to fall rye before the end of August, but instead of doing this he left it till last week to seed the land to rye with a tiller combine, without burning the stubble or even plowing the land. This I consider to be just wasting the seed, which at this late date will not germinate, if it does the plants will not have sufficient time to become properly rooted, before frost comes "killing them off".

The lease in the first place was rather loosely drawn as there was no provision made for the summerfallowing of a specified acreage each year. A man like Harrold was quick to take advantage of this, with the results as outlined in the reports submitted.
Provision is made in the lease however for the cancellation of the agreement between November 15th & February 15th, and with this in mind, I think it might be just as well if I, or Mr. Woodworth were given instructions to look around for a more suitable occupant, who would farm the place according to the plan submitted, and if such a man is found, Harold could be given notice of cancellation of his agreement.

I might say that Mr. Woodworth is not in favor of a five year lease being given to anyone, as he feels that with the end of the war, there should be no difficulty in obtaining the required help at the school to allow them to farm the place themselves. But, supposing a lease were granted for a term of five years, provision could be made for cancellation between seasons - providing for the indemnifying of the lessees for any surplus labor done - from which he would not get any returns.

As an alternative, money could possibly be found to hire all the work done on the farm this next year & from then on the crops raised on the land should pay for all future costs of operations.

This of course would require rather close supervision.

J.T. Reunt,
Acting Indian Agent.

Further to my letter of January 17th, in which I advised you that I had arranged a meeting for this morning at Mr. Mather's office—

Mr. Fontaine, the district agriculturist, who was at the meeting, was of the opinion that such a date should be set so that it should be just as early as possible and in the case of a rye crop it could be quite early, so as to allow of lots of time for reseeding if necessary and that he was ready willing to act in the matter, along with the other authorities interested.

I showed Mr. Fontaine the statement of costs as submitted by Mr. Harold in connection with the seeding of the 40 acres to rye and he was of the same opinion as Mr. Mather, in that the charges were excessive so that they should be revised downwards, in the event of the Department deciding to pay off Harold for the work done.

I asked Mr. Mather & Mr. Fontaine if they were prepared to give me figures as usually paid in the neighbourhood for work
work of this nature and they were and in regard to the charge of $2.03 for the seed, they both remembered that Harold had told us at the previous meeting that the seed had cost him $1.53 per bushel & that he was not entitled to charge any more.

It would have to be determined also whether any barrowing was done on the land, which I myself would be prepared to dispute, as I went over the ground some little time after it had been seeded & the disc marks of the tiller-combine were quite distinct.

With regard to the charge for summerfallowing the 37 acres; this too is out of line & further, as an offset against this there was 162 acres of land prepared for crop by the school, part of which work was hired done, in 1943 and all Harold had to do, was to drill the crop in, in 1944.

Further to your letter No. 100-0-9 of December 26th, last, and our letter of the 7th instant, even number, with enclosures: I beg to report that I intended leaving here on the evening of the 6th instant for Rocky Mountain House, and from there proceed to Edmonton, but unfortunately I was put to bed by the Doctor on the P.M. of Sunday, the 6th, with a very bad attack of 'Flu, which kept me there for a few days, and left me somewhat weak afterwards, for which reason I did not go to Edmonton until the 22nd.

On the 24th instant, together with Mr. J.T. Faunt, Acting Indian Agent, we met Mr. J.G. Harrold in Edmonton, when he handed to Mr. Faunt a statement of his claim for expenses incurred for seeding 80 acres to Fall Rye and summerfallowing 37 acres in 1945. I told Mr. Harrold there and then, that I considered his claim quite high, and that he would no doubt be asked for receipted statements for certain charges made.

We (Mr. Faunt and I) pointed out to him that he had previously said that the Rye seed had cost him $1.53 per bushel; his reply was that he had had difficulty in finding this seed; that the grain he purchased was dirty, and he had to clean it. He also remarked that the price of Rye was now more than $2.00 a bushel. We also remarked to him that we considered the charges for trucking ($28.00) were high.

Mr. Faunt also remarked that in his opinion the charge for harrowing was not a fair one.

Mr. Faunt drew his attention to the fact that when he took the farm over in September, 1944, there were 182 acres of summerfallow; to this Harrold remarked that this was not good summerfallow; that it had not been kept black by cultivation, and that weeds thereon were tall. He admitted seeding it in 1945 without extra cultivation. Mr. Faunt remarked that these 182 acres should offset the 37 acres he summerfallowed in 1945, and then some.

To all this Harrold did not have much to say, other than that if his lease were cancelled, he would lose money, as he had ordered a new 24-run Seed Drill. He said that he was willing (preferred) to harvest the 80 acres of Rye, as Rye was at a high price at present. He then remarked that he had not yet received notice of cancellation of his lease.

I told him that a report would be made to the Branch of our interview, and that if they decided to cancel his contract, which was what we (Mr. Faunt and myself) had already recommended, he would receive notice, by mail, from Ottawa. This ended our interview with Mr. Harrold.

(OVER)
We then met Rev. J.F. Woodsworth, Principal of the School, who is interested in this farm, as he receives one-third share of all crops grown thereon by the lessee. The point I wanted to bring before Mr. Woodsworth was that any expenditure (payments) made to Mr. Harrold or a new tenant (Mr. Brabant) for 100 acres of summerfallow this year (1946), if paid by the Branch, should be refundable and paid from the proceeds of the School's share of the crop.

Rev. Mr. Woodsworth said he considered the amount of the claim (statement) submitted by Mr. Harrold to be excessive; he disagreed with the remark made to Mr. Faunt and myself by Harrold that the weeds were "high" on the summerfallow (182 acres), pointing out that Harrold had seeded it without any special cultivation.

I then pointed out to Mr. Faunt and Rev. Mr. Woodsworth that if we allowed Harrold to retain his interest in the 80 acres of Rye during 1946, there should be a cut-off date set, at which time it should be decided whether to leave it grow and mature, or plow it under. Mr. Faunt has stated that this Rye was poorly farmed, and he has very little hope that it will be a good crop because of the class of work done, unless we have a very favourable season next summer. My reason for wanting a cut-off date is to enable us to cultivate (plow) this 80 acres and seed it to oats in proper time. I suggested consulting Mr. H.J. Mather, Supervisor, Soil Conservation and Weed Control, for the Province, regarding this point as it would be well to have an independent and competent party make the decision. We phoned his office for an appointment, but were told that he was out of the City and would not return before Saturday A.M., I then asked Mr. Faunt to interview him, which he has done. (Vide his letters enclosed herewith).

My recommendation is, that Mr. Harrold's contract be cancelled immediately on all but the 80 acres of fall Rye, and that this be left to him on the understanding that this crop will be inspected by an independent party who shall decide whether to leave same to mature or plow it under; if plowed under, Mr. Harrold is to have no claim whatever against us.

Notice of cancellation should be in his hands before February 15th, next. His address is P.O. Box #535, Edmonton, Alberta. (Vide his statement of claim).

Re: Jack Harrold

Dear Jim:

Your letter of June 12th received.

It is not a question of the Officials of the Department helping Jack. It is a question of the Dominion of Canada being fair and reasonable with a common, ordinary, every day citizen of Canada.

At no time was there ever any complaint of any kind that Jack Harrold was not doing his best to keep ahead of the weeds, and when the writer of the letter to you says that Jack Harrold was not complying with the terms of his lease, Jack does not know what he is talking about. No complaint was ever made that Jack was not fully carrying out the terms of his lease, nor was any complaint of any kind ever heard.

I have hunted on this land for many years and know it all just like a book. I have never in my life seen a farm so badly infested with sow thistle. I defy any human being to walk through the bush and open land from the North to South where it is bush land without being smothered with sow thistle. Now this is not on cultivated land and never has been cultivated, but I never in my life saw such a crop of sow thistle. The farm is simply polluted and has been for years to the knowledge of the Superintendent of the School, the Weed Inspector, the Indian Agent and the Provincial Department of Agriculture.

Finally last summer the Weed Inspector, the Supervisor under our Provincial Agricultural Service Board Act, the Indian Agent, Dr. Woodsworth, the principal of the School, Mr. Mather of the Provincial Department of Agriculture and Jack Harrold met. It was then suggested that the lease be extended for a period of six years rather than one year which it had to run.

The District Agriculturist, the Weed Inspector, the Indian Agent and Dr. Woodsworth set out a rotation of crops for Jack Harrold to follow for the remaining six years. One of the suggestions was that Jack was to prepare and seed down the 80 acres in question to rye, in addition to summerfallowing properly the 38 acres which he was then doing. This report was to be

..... sent down
sent down to Ottawa which I believe was done and the Officials in Ottawa have this report.

Pursuant to this recommendation, Jack proceeded to complete the summerfallowing and to seed down the 80 acres to rye.

The excuse the Indian Agent now gives is that Ottawa did not approve of the report and recommendation and Jack took his chances without the approval of the authorities at Ottawa. Now what is the answer to this suggestion. Here it is: Ottawa moves very slowly. Jack arranged for his lease in March, 1944, but never received the lease until November, 1944, after he had already put his crop in and harvested it. He fully expected the recommendation to be carried out by the Officials at Ottawa and had he waited for a reply, it probably would not have been received until November, 1946.

Certainly had Jack Harold realized or known that his lease was going to be cancelled, he certainly would not have gone to the expense of summer and keeping back 38 acres and preparing and seeding to rye the 80 acres in question.

It may be that the attitude of the Officials of the Department is as mentioned in the memorandum to you, but I cannot believe that such is the attitude of the Government of Canada. It is ridiculous for the person sending you the memorandum to say the lease was first granted on September 1st, 1944. It was not delivered until November, 1944, but the arrangements were made for the lease in the early Spring and Jack cropped the land that season.

There is not a farmer in Alberta who leases a farm on which the tenant has done summerfallowing and the owner by virtue of a clause in the lease to cancel in the event of sale but what makes a fair and reasonable allowance to his tenant for extra work done on the farm.

I might add that in addition to sow thistles, Canadian thistles also abound and grow right in the bush so thick that you simply cannot walk through it. In fact three years ago, I had my little girl with me and she had to turn back because of thistles.

Yours sincerely,

(SGD) Fraser Duncan.

However on September 23rd, 1945, the Indian Affairs Branch received a report from Indian Agent Faunt about this 80 acres which Mr. Harrold seeded. His letter of that date reads as follows: "To begin with, the 80 acres which were seeded to barley this year and which he was told to swath & combine at the beginning of August & then to burn off the stubble to kill the weed seeds. This I consider was just wasting the seed, which at this late date will not germinate & if it does the plants will not have sufficient time to become properly rooted, before frost comes & kills them off."

Dear Doctor Dorsey:

Re: Edmonton Indian Residential School.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of January 29th with reference to the 1946 occupation by Mr. Van Brabant of part of the Edmonton Indian Residential School land. While the information which you have requested was given you verbally on your recent visit to the Department, it is thought you would like to have it on record as well.

As far back as January, 1946, we learned that Mr. Van Brabant was ready to take over the land on a leasing agreement, but at that time there was some difference of opinion as to the term which should be given and Van Brabant did not express any definite statement that he would lease on the Department's terms. Nothing further was heard concerning Van Brabant until the middle of July when Agent Faunt advised us that Van Brabant was prepared to farm the place on a two-third - one-third basis starting with the present crop, to summerfallow a reasonable amount each year, and at the end of the term leave not less than one hundred acres of summerfallowed land, and at that time Agent Faunt recommended the lease be granted for a five-year period.

Unfortunately, at the date this advice was received at the Department we were involved in attempting to straighten out the claim of Mr. Harold, the previous tenant, and it is assumed that for this reason no reply was made to Agent Faunt regarding the use of the property by Van Brabant and I cannot find that any reply was in fact made to him and this is borne out by the fact that on September 30th last, E. A. Robertson, the Clerk in Charge

The Reverend Doctor George Dorsey,
Secretary, Board of Home Missions,
The United Church of Canada,
299 Queen Street West,
Toronto 2 B, Ontario.
of the Edmonton Agency, inquired as to whether any decision had been made re granting a lease to Van Brabant, for, as he stated in his letter, "Mr. Van Brabant is getting a little anxious about his lease."

In short, therefore, although Agent Faunt recommended a lease to Van Brabant, the recommendation was never carried out and this Branch at no time stated to any one in writing that the Van Brabant lease had been approved.

The foregoing is the information as revealed by our files with the exception that apparently Agent Faunt, prior to recommending the lease to us, had told Van Brabant to go ahead and put in crop on Plots Nos. 2 and 3 of the farm and also gave him permission to seed to barley and oats Plot No. 4. As you are aware, Van Brabant summerfallowed Plots Nos. 1, 5 and 6. I understand that you expect to visit Edmonton shortly and, if so, you will be able to check the foregoing with Mr. Faunt and ascertain exactly what arrangements he may have made with Van Brabant other than those mentioned above.

While at Edmonton School on Aug. 27th, I was advised by Mr. Staley that he had been approached by the Morinville Municipal District in regard to some assistance with a road which borders the west side of the school farm. As you no doubt know the road situation into the school is very bad during the winter and also during wet periods in summer, the roads are practically impassable at present.

The Municipal District are high grading and graveling the road along Sturgeon River from St. Albert to 127th St. The latter Street borders the East side of the school property and the proposed gravel road would pass along the north boundary of the school farm.

There is a side road on the west side of the farm which runs along the school property for approximately 1 mile and passes the school gate. The municipality has offered to high-grade this road and gravel the hill where the road comes up from the river bottom if the department will pay the amount of $250.00 as a portion of the cost. In connection with the road to be gravelled I might say that the cost of this operation is borne equally by the municipality and the individual farmers whose property it runs through.

The $250.00 they have asked for will not amount to one-half of the cost of the road past the west boundary of the property and they are not asking any contributions for the graveling north of the property.

(over)
If funds are available I would strongly recommend this expenditure as it will provide a badly needed all weather road into the school at a very low cost.

Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION

Uncleared Land at Edmonton Residential School

On January 22, 1951, the former Superintendent of Education wrote to the Reverend Dr. Dorey as follows:

"I am also prepared to recommend to the Director that an expenditure of $5,000.00 of school funds be authorized for the clearing of additional land for farm purposes. I believe that the additional revenue thus obtained would more than repay the $5,000 thus used."

I cannot find on any of our files a reply from the Reverend Dr. Dorey, to this letter. In a report on file 110/25-1-753 dated June 15, 1949, I urged that this land be cleared and put into cultivation for school purposes. Mr. Regional Supervisor Gooderham countered on July 13, 1949, with the suggestion that the land be leased to an outsider, but your previous experience with leases at this school was not such as to encourage a resumption of such procedures.

I suggest now that the Department have the land cleared by contract. There are, within 50 miles of Edmonton, several operators who have the sort of machine that enables them to clear off the trees and brush on land such as the Edmonton school land efficiently and quickly and at a predetermined cost. It would, I think, be possible to get competitive bids. The $5,000.00 mentioned above would go a long way to doing all the work necessary to be done by outsiders.

If our field officials could now be authorized
to get competitive bids on this job, it might be possible to include in the supplementary estimates an item covering this project.

The resulting revenue from the use of this additional land should enable the Department to retard increasing the per capita grant at this residential school and thus effect a worthwhile return on the investment.

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

Sir,

re - Philip Stephens, Pupil at the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

I am in receipt of an application from Mrs. Martha Rebecca Stephens, an Indian of this Agency, asking for the return of her son, Philip Stephens, who is, at present, a pupil of the Indian Residential School, Edmonton, Alberta.

Mrs. Stephens is a widow residing on the Hazelton Reserve. Of late years she has been very sickly and has no one to look after her except a mentally deficient son. She has been receiving relief regularly from this office.

She states that if Philip is sent home he will be able to hunt, cultivate the garden and catch fish, sufficient to keep her off relief.

I am of opinion that Philip, who will be 18 years of age in October, should be returned to his home this year in order to help his mother. He should also acquire hunting and trapping knowledge in order to help support the family and himself.

I am enclosing the Certificate of Baptism of this boy, showing the date of his birth, and shall be glad if you will kindly return it to me after perusal.

Encl.

Your obedient servant,

GCM/SM.

The Secretary;

Dear Sir;

About the middle of August I wrote the Department regarding the delay of the children from the Saddle Lake Agency in returning to school on account of an epidemic of Whooping-Cough. I understand Mr. Agent Gullion also wrote the Department and suggested that the full per capita be allowed because of the circumstances. It will soon be time to make out the September report and I shall be glad of instructions from the Department as to what allowance should be made. I may say that about the only saving we have is that of food and clothing for the sixty odd children who are not back. Otherwise our expenses are the same for overhead, teachers etc. The return of pupils from the other reserves is quite satisfactory, and if it had not been for this outbreak of sickness we would have had a full school. As the Department is aware I require my full per capita of $50 to properly carry on the work of this school.

Yours Truly;

[Signature]

Principal.

Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant, with reference to children from the Saddle Lake Agency who did not return to the Edmonton Indian Residential School upon the expiry of their leave owing to illness on the reserve.

In the case of each child who was allowed home on holidays and who did not return upon the expiry of his leave, grant should only be requested for forty-three (43) days, namely the holiday leave for which grant is allowed.

Dear Sir:

Last Monday the 23rd of this month I met our Indian Inspector, Mr. Christianson, and had a talk with him in regard of my children who are wishing to get an education. Mr. Christianson, who has advised me to write to you personally asking you if you could take my children into your school.

My two girls Mildred, age fourteen, Grace age twelve, are wishing very much to get an education as we have no school close around here, and they are not able to go to school the distance being too far. It is my sincere wish to have my children to be educated. I think I have done my part in teaching them to talk English from babyhood and I know they are eager to learn how to read and write. They have had a good start at home and I know they will learn fast in school. I would be very glad if you could take them in as soon as you can — the sooner they start in school the better, because they should have been in school before now.

There is one thing in particular I would like to ask: I have a boy who is school age, 9, but he belongs to the Anglican Church as my husband belongs to that Church. Could he go to your school? Of course my husband is not home just now and have not talked to him about this matter yet.

All my four girls and myself we belong to the United Church. My husband and my four little boys all belong to the Church of England.

Mr. Christianson says he will help me all he can to have my children in school and I hope you will too, Mr. Woodsworth. I take Treaty yet and I think my children should be taken into an Indian school like the rest.

Hoping you will write to me soon and let me know what you think about this matter.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) ELIZA JANE HOWSE

Dear Sir;

Numerous requests have come from the Babine Agency for the return of their children for holidays. I have at present about 35 fro this agency. I have been planning to let about half of this number go, as most of these 18 are nearly 18 years of age, or at least over 16 and should be away for various reasons. Of the other children who would remain at the school, most of them are young. Some have not been home for three or four years, and in some cases longer. I have received some very insistant requests for children. Two months which is our holiday period this year seems a long time for about 20 little boys and girls to remain on the school campus while their companions are away. What shall I do? I know the risk of not getting them back. I lost a lot two years ago. None were home last year. What financial arrangement will the Department consider. I shall be glad of some definite instructions from the Department as soon as possible, either by letter or wire. I have written to the Acting Agent at Hazelton asking for his recommendation.

Reverend Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to the children from the Babine Agency who have been attending the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

It is noted that eighteen (18) of these children are being discharged at the end of the present academic year.

Regarding the remaining seventeen (17), you should ascertain from the Acting Indian Agent at Hazelton whether or not their parents are living and in a position to properly care for them. If so, you might let me know what it would cost to send these home for vacation.

If there are any of these seventeen (17) children whose parents are dead or whose parents, though living, are unable to properly provide for them, it is believed inadvisable to even consider allowing them home for holidays.

On receipt of your reply regarding the estimate of the cost requested in the preceding part of this letter, you will be advised by wire with regard to the Department's decision.

There are about five boys at the Edmonton Indian Residential School who should not have been permitted to leave the day school here. I strongly recommend that they be sent back to Kitwanga. I understand that their parents also desire this. Three of the above are the sons of Wallace Morgan, and the remaining two are Jeffry and James Fowler.

I would further recommend that in future if Indian children have to be sent to a residential school from the Babine Agency they be sent to St. Michael's Alert Bay, and not to Edmonton. The parents are I am informed very anxious that their children be not sent to Edmonton and from what I have seen lately I am very much afraid that to send B.C. children to Edmonton to mix with Indians of such a different environment is neither fair to the children themselves or a wise expenditure of money. The school work is so different from our work in B.C. that the children are not able to take the same Grades on their return here. I do not believe that the Indian children sent to Alberta learn anything of the slightest use to them on the B.C. Reserves.

I must also mention the case of MELBA WILITZU age 10 Grade I who has no parents alive and is just being made a slave of by others. She should be a residential school, and I recommend that an experiment be made and the child sent to St. Michael's if she can pass the medical tests and the Principal of St. Michael's will enter this recruiting field.

IN FORWARDING THE ABOVE REPORT TO MAJOR D. M. MACKAY, INDIAN COMMISSIONER, MR. BARRY WRITES AS FOLLOWS:

I may say that I am very unhappy with regard to the lack of progress made by the Indian pupils going to the residential school near Edmonton. I am told that the B.C. Indians are quite out of touch with various activities there as they are not considered by the Indians on the Alberta side of the Rocky Mountains as of the same stock. If children must be sent to a residential school, I certainly consider that Alert Bay would be the most suitable. The Indian parents are complaining of the long distance to Edmonton, and the fact that they do not see their children in some cases for years. The whole system of instruction at Edmonton appears to be different to that followed in British Columbia, and I would ask you to support my recommendation if you can see your way to do so.

Dear Sir;

It is with regret that I call your attention to the expulsion of Emily Little Poplar Pupil No.086. on IIth of February 1938.

As indicated in the report Emily was a girl of some ability and until last fall we had no other thought than that she would complete her year and graduate honourably this coming Summer. However during the fall she gave indications of insubordination, which increased in the number of violations of discipline, and also in the violence which attended her outbreaks. At various times she not only defied various members of the staff, but even the Matron and myself. Her conduct began to spread to other pupils and seriously threatened the whole discipline of the school. Being a young woman we did not consider it wise to use severe corporal punishment, as this might raise unlooked for criticism. After a final outbreak of temper on her part, and after a great deal of thought and consideration on my part I decided to send her home. The girl admitted that she had been working to this end, and she gave no evidence of a desire to do better. So I was not able to do other than I did. I may say that her expulsion has made a great difference in the whole atmosphere of the school. I may also say that there is a background at home on the Reserve at Hobbema for this case. I trust my action is approved by The Department.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

Since this boy has been my pupil he has shown keen interest in his school work and has attended regularly.

Dear Sir:
