In regard to Wm. Lapotac. This child was sent to the school for the purpose of getting him into the T.B. ward of the General Hospital. Dr. Williamson declined to sign the health certificate and my impression is that I sent the forms to Mr. Leight to deal with. However Mr. Leight cannot locate these forms. However he obtained authority to have the boy sent to hospital. See letter of Mr. Leight of Sept. 10th 1938 to Mr. Schmidt enclosing a report from Dr. Davidson. Also letter of October 8th 1938 from XXXXXX Mr. Leight Mr. Schmidt to Mr. Leight with authority from Mr. Baker to have the child admitted to hospital. The child was in the school but a few days.

Case of Gordon Crowchild:- This lad is from Sarcee Reserve. His parents were very anxious to have him in this school as they live some distance from their day school. The boy already has a brother here, admitted some time ago. The Agent Dr. Murray appeared to approve of the move. Application forms were sent to Dr. Murray along with health certificate. I presume these forms are now in the hands of Dr. Murray or have been forwarded to Ottawa. The application was made out immediately upon the arrival of the lad in the school and at once forwarded to the Agent for approval.

XXXXXXX In regard to the other eight cases they ALL belong to the Saddle Lake Agency. ALL application forms together with completed health certificates were IMMEDIATELY sent to your Indian Agent upon the arrival of the child at this school. In the past I have sent your requests to the agent for the forwarding of these forms to Ottawa. Dear Sir,

I enclose herewith Quarterly Report for this School ended Sept. 30th 1939.

You will note that there are 147 names on the roll. In a number of cases I have recommended the discharge of pupils. In a few cases sickness at home has prevented immediate return, but in practically all these cases I have been assured that the pupils will be returned as soon as possible.

On the report you will note that 25 pupils did not return from the Saddle Lake Agency. Mr. Gullion assured me that these would be in by Oct. 1st. To date no word has been received as to their return. I have been unable to secure from Mr. Gullion any word as to why they have not returned or at least a sufficient reason why. As you are aware this involves a serious financial loss to the school, and I do not think this wholesale neglect to return should be allowed to pass without notice. Sir:

I beg to report that on September 1st, 1938 Margaret Sharphead granddaughter of John Sharphead No.168 Enoch Band, was admitted into the Edmonton Residential School, her application for admission shows her religion as Protestant and was signed by John Sharphead as father. Her admission was authorized by Departmental letter No.110-0-10 of November 2nd, 1938.

I am now in receipt of a letter from the Reverend Sister Superior, Principal, Youville Residential School stating that having been informed that this child was of Catholic decent she had made research to ascertain the fact and that evidence has come in the form of a baptismal certificate, a copy being sent to me and is attached hereto.

For the information of the Department I beg to report that upon receipt of this letter I have interviewed John Sharphead and have obtained the following information; this is an illegitimate child, the father was William Ward No.196 Enoch Band, and the mother Eliza Story step-daughter of John Sharphead, the child was raised by Sharphead and is paid Treaty under his ticket, the mother afterwards married a half-breed by the name of Charlie Norwest, but the child was left with Sharphead. The mother is still in Treaty and paid under Ticket No.214 Enoch Band.

When I took over the duties of Indian Agent at this Agency I was always led to believe that this child was John Sharphead's daughter, she was born on March 12th, 1929 and in 1929 was paid Treaty under John Sharphead's Ticket, the notation in the Treaty book being "girl born" this payment was made by Mr Geo H Race who was Indian Agent at this Agency at that time.

John Sharphead was a Protestant but turned Roman Catholic, he was himself educated at the Red Deer Residential School and it is his wish that Margaret be educated at the Edmonton Residential School. The Reverend Sister Superior states that it is her duty to claim for this child her rights and that the child is entitled to a Catholic education under the Indian Act.

It is quite true that the father William Ward is a Roman Catholic but he did not do anything towards raising the child and John Sharphead respectfully asks that the child be educated in the Edmonton Residential School.

Will the Department please advise me what action if any to take in this matter.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

G. C. Leight,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your 110-0-11 of the 3rd instant, regarding the Principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School, experiencing a difficulty in securing the number of pupils for which per capita grant is allowed by the Department.

I have endeavoured to co-operate to the fullest extent with the Principals of both schools, in seeing that all children of school age attend school.

I have a problem at this Agency which is acute. There are a large number of R.C. children of school age who are not attending school. In my report for the month of September I suggested that I be allowed to use my authority under Sec. 10, Sub. Sec. 3 & 4 of the Indian Act for R.C. children and follow this up with the Protestant children. I meet with strenuous opposition from Protestant parents, who use for an excuse that the R.C. children do not have to go to school, so they won't send their children. Of course this is only an excuse. I have tried persuasion but to no avail.

May I suggest that the following action be taken:

(a). Children who have been admitted to school, but have not returned: That Sec. 10, Sub. Sec. 3 of the Indian Act, be acted upon, and if this fails to have the desired effect, that Sub. Sec. 4 be evoked.

(b). Children who are of school age but have not yet been presented at school for admission: That Rev. Mr. Law, United Church Missionary at this Agency, use his best endeavour to persuade the parents to send their children to school. If this fails, then Sec. 10, Sub. Sec. 3 & 4 be evoked.

I am sending a copy of this letter to the Rev. Mr. Woodsworth and asking him to forward me his reactions to these suggestions.

Your obedient servant,

Alfred G. B. Lewis,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant and to thank you for the information contained therein.

I can readily appreciate the difficulties you may experience in persuading the United Church children to attend at Edmonton while a number of Roman Catholic children are absent from school on the reserve.

The records here indicate that we are paying grant for 140 pupils at the Ermineskin residential school. The claim of this school for additional pupilage will be carefully considered when the 1940-41 estimates are under consideration. In view of the war conditions now confronting us, however, I am not in a position to state just what action the Government is likely to take. I have been wondering if you ever discussed with the Principal the advisability of having a class of day school pupils organized at Ermineskins as a temporary measure. If a sufficient number of Roman Catholic children live comparatively close to the school, this experiment might be undertaken on the understanding that the children would be provided with instruction and a noon-day lunch. Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your 110-0-10 of the 23rd ultimo, re. children at this Agency who are absent from school, both Roman Catholic and Protestant.

Regarding the R.C. children attending Day School, this phase has been seriously considered several times since I have been here, but it is considered out of the question owing to the difficulties involved.

When I first came here, pupils at Ermineskin School were constantly in and out of school, visiting at their homes; this was made possible by the large number of children over the 140 allowed for grant earning pupils, so that quite a number of children could be absent without the total number in school at any time being below 140.

Since this time there have been two new principals and they have given me every co-operation in stopping this practice, and of course the Indian parents do not like this. They still think they should get their children out for a week or more whenever they ask. The children also think they are not being treated fairly by this privilege being withdrawn.

The Principal is quite anxious to help us in any way possible, but he is of the opinion that at present, at any rate, the establishment of a day school would tend to have disgruntled parents of grant earning pupils insist that their children also be day school pupils and the whole school system be disrupted.

It would also be necessary, if day schools for these children who cannot be accommodated in the Residential School, be established, to organise two other buildings as schools for children who live too far away to attend Ermineskin School. One at Louis Bull's Reserve and one at the South end of Samson's Reserve. This is out of the question owing to insufficient teaching staff for this purpose.

To overcome, in a small degree, the school problem, I with the assistance of the school authorities, organised a night school with Rev. Father Lawert, O.M.I., as teacher. This only lasted a few weeks as someone started a rumour that as soon as the school was going good the attendance would be made compulsory, and all I could do to rectify this was unavailing and the night school died a natural death.

You will readily see the difficulty I have in trying to get things to run smoothly, but I do hope some day to have everything running in a businesslike manner.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

During the fall and early winter there was some correspondence between the various agents and the Department in regard to recruiting for this school in order to bring the attendance up to a satisfactory point. During the last week I have had a very satisfactory conversation with Mr. Gullion of the Saddle Lake Agency in regard to the problem of recruiting at that point. It would appear that there are a certain number of complaints, most of which are without any reasonable foundation. Some of the parents of Protestant connection are attempting to send their children to the Blue Quill R. C. School, and at the present time certain children are present in that school without being admitted by the Department, and are being kept there against the approval of the Indian Agent. The Indian Agent informs me that there are R. C. children on the Reserve who are unable to go to this school because of lack of room, and it seems an unreasonable thing that children of undoubted Protestant connection should be in residence.

As the Department is aware there are certain times when through some reaction on the part of a family or band the parents try to get their children into another school than that of their religious connection. As far as I can make out this is the case in
connection with the following children:

A daughter of Rhuben Bull of Goodfish Lake.

Three children of Tommy Heule

A boy-Miles Hunter

Three Hunter children John, Anna, and Annie children of Norman Hunter.

Mr. Gullion is writing the Department in connection with these cases and is anxious to have them put in this school. I do not think that there is any deep seated objection to sending the children here and I believe that some definite instructions from the Department would greatly assist your Agent.

During the last months since the opening of school I have been trying to build up my attendance in accord with correspondence with the Department, and if I secure these children, it may quiet the objectors there and assist with further recruiting.

Reverend Sir:

A review of the December quarter return of the Edmonton Indian Residential School shows the following pupils over the age of 16:

No. 098 Vera Rabbit          No. 0120 Jenny Bull
" 0113 Mary Steinhauer       " 0148 Annie Ward
" 0114 Charlotte Hunter     " 0150 Ruth Makokis
" 0118 Olive Whitford       " 0155 Lena Waskatineau

No application for retaining these children in your school appears to have been received and in this connection I wish to direct your attention to circular letter of July 21, 1939, a copy of which is enclosed.

As pointed out in the circular letter the Department realizes that frequently there are reasons for keeping certain children after they reach the age of 16 but at the same time the consent of the Superintendent General (Minister) must be obtained.

I may add that in the past the Department has been favourably disposed to allowing certain pupils, especially girls, to remain in residential schools after they reach the age of 16 if good reasons for such action are given by the Principal and approved by the Indian Agent. However, in view of the fact that the number of children of school age is apparently increasing and the further consideration that due to the conditions now confronting us there is no immediate prospect of our securing funds to provide increased pupilage at Indian residential schools, it is considered that in future it will be necessary to adhere more strictly to the provision of the Indian Act requiring discharge of pupils at 16 years of age.

Rev. J. F. Woodsworth, B.A.,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Edmonton, Alta.
I feel you will agree with me that it is not fair to deprive children of education simply because the accommodation that might be available for them in a residential school is being used by those who have had the advantage of residential school training for some years and who have reached the age of 16 years.

Until further advised you should make arrangements for the discharge of pupils when they reach the age of 16 unless there are some very exceptional circumstances and in this event full particulars should be given to the Department and our permission obtained before such pupils reach the age of 16.

With the above in mind I desire to hear from you at the earliest possible date stating the date on which the pupils mentioned in the first part of this letter can be discharged from your school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir;

I have your letter of 23rd Inst. No. II0-0-10 in reference to eight girls, pupils of this school who are here over the age of 16 years.

In regard to the closing paragraph of your letter I may say that the eight girls mentioned in your letter can be discharged from school the end of this coming June. It is at this time that we have our closing exercises when pupils who have attained the age required are honourably discharged. I trust this arrangement is satisfactory to The Department.

Of course there is the larger question of education which I have been trying for years to carry out in this school. With our Vocational objective in mind I feel that the best years that a boy or girl puts in at school where such a program exists, is between the ages of 16 and 18 or over. I have regretted the tendency during the last few years to discharge children at 16 years of age.

As you probably know, my problem is not with overcrowding of young children. I would like to see more come along. You will no doubt have observed that a number of children under the age are still on the reserve, and are not being sent in.

Yours Truly,

J.F. Woodsworth
Principal.
Ottawa, March 5, 1940.

Dear Mr. Woodsworth:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of February 28, written by you in reply to Mr. Phelan's communication dated February 23, 1940.

It is noted that the eight girls referred to by Mr. Phelan can be discharged from your school at the end of the present academic year.

I find it exceedingly difficult to adjust the educational policy of the Department to the war conditions now confronting us. The Indian school population of Canada is increasing at the rate of approximately 300 pupils per annum. Despite this fact, I have no assurance at this date that we shall be able to proceed with our regular building program at any time throughout the duration of the war. If this building program is suspended, our educational institutions already in operation are likely to be taxed to the utmost to accommodate the steadily increasing school population. I feel, therefore, that our first duty is to the pupils ranging in age between 7 and 16. Should money be available at any time in the immediate future to proceed with our regular building program, the educational period of a number of our brighter pupils at residential schools might be extended.

I am somewhat disturbed at the information that has reached me with respect to the location of your Edmonton school and the difficulty experienced in recruiting pupils. The Indian agent, in a lengthy letter dated February 13, states:

"The various points raised here were all brought up and discussed with Mr. Woodsworth at Edmonton".

You are reasonably familiar with the tendency on the part of certain Indian parents to send their children to the Blue Quills school and the growing demand for the establishment of day schools on certain reserves. It is my personal opinion that these conditions are not likely to improve unless some attempt is made by the United Church or by the Department or by both to adjust them. I am frankly of the opinion that with a less efficient principal in charge of the school we would be at this date experiencing considerable difficulty in financing the institution, which fact in itself prompts me to think of the future.

You might let me know if you have ever seriously considered -

Reverend J. F. Woodsworth, B.A.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Edmonton, Alberta.
considered the desirability of having a thorough survey made of the Indian reserves from which your pupils are recruited, with the object of determining what type of educational institution would be best adapted to the needs of the Indian population. If such a survey were undertaken and the recommendations made therein approved by the members of the Home Mission Board, the Government would have before it valuable information to guide them in working out a worthwhile program, for this particular section of Alberta. I can't at the moment think of a number of steps that might be taken but I am not at all sure that these would be acceptable to the church authorities. It seems to me very regrettable that the Edmonton school, a very costly institution insofar as its construction is concerned, was established in its present location.

You might at your convenience let me have any comments you may care to send forward in respect to these matters.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
March 27th 1940.

Dear Sir:-

Ottawa,

Dear Sir;

On March 18th I sent to the Department my voucher No. 968 for a refund on transportation amounting to $390.95.

To date I have not heard from the Department regarding the consideration of this account. For many years back the Department has given consideration to similar accounts either in whole or in part. Yours Truly;

J.R. Goodsworth,
Principal.
Ottawa,
May 14, 1940.

Reverend Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of the 11th instant regarding your voucher No. 968. At the time the voucher reached the Department no funds were available and since that time we have secured a Governor General's Warrant covering part of our appropriation.

Very careful consideration has been given to the account which you submitted but it is found that owing to a drastic reduction in our appropriation we can only allow an amount of $150.00 toward the transportation of children to and from the Edmonton School this year. At the present time I am unable to state what amount, if any, can be allowed for transportation of pupils during the current fiscal year. Under these circumstances you should take advantage of every possible means of having the children brought to and from the school by the parents without expense.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. J. F. Woodsworth,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Edmonton, Alta.

Dear Sir:

We have a great deal of difficulty in obtaining the application forms from Indian Agent Gullion in connection with children admitted to the Edmonton Residential School. Mr. Christianson wrote to Mr. Gullion on April 22 regarding his remissness in this regard. He replied in a letter dated May 1 that he would forward shortly application forms for Francis Jackson, Annie Hunter and Lillian Hunter who had been in the Edmonton School for several months. As these forms had not reached us by July 10 I again wrote to Mr. Gullion and instructed him to forward them at once. He has not yet done so.

I think you will realize that it is a great waste of time to be obliged to write several letters to an Indian Agent simply for the purpose of obtaining application forms which should be prepared and forwarded to the Department immediately on the admission of a child to a residential school. I should, therefore, appreciate anything you can do to hasten the forwarding of the forms for the children mentioned above.

On the September quarter return it is noted that George Breast was admitted to the school during the quarter. There is no sign of the application for this boy and judging by Mr. Gullion's actions in the past there is very little likelihood of its reaching here for several months unless you are successful in making him carry out his duties in this particular regard.

Yours truly,

Mr. C.P. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alta.

Dear Sir,

I am writing you two letters from Alex Bull of Sarcee Agency regarding one of his girls whom he wishes to be admitted to this school - Alex is related to the Bull family of Louis Bull Band of Hobema. For years we have had their children in this school and Alex himself a graduate of the old Red Deer School. He is apparently very anxious for his children to be here - Mr. Murray, the Agent, is not sure of his ground, and of course I would not go over his head, and wrote him to that effect.

I may say I have at present two Sarcee boys in this school who are here with recommendation of the Agent. It is quite possible that Alex Bull may have a good reason for his request. I shall be glad to have the children as my school is not full.

Yours Truly,

J. F. Woodsworth
Principal

Kindly let me know your attitude in the matter.

Reverend Sir:

Sir,

Referring to your letter No. 403-11A.U. of the 4th instant in the first paragraph of which you inquire regarding applications for admission to the Edmonton Residential school of Francis Jackson, Lillian Hunter and Annie Hunter, I beg to inform you that in this reply, I wish to deal particularly with the latter child, Annie Hunter. This child is on the roll of the Edmonton Indian Residential school, having been placed in that institution in October 1936. While Annie Hunter was in the Edmonton school from this date to the end of the June term in 1939, the parents refused to sign the application for admission.

In November 1939, the parents voluntarily placed Annie in the Blue Quill's Indian Residential school. The father, Norman Hunter, offered to sign the application for admission of Annie into the Blue Quill's Residential school and he signed the form which I enclose herewith, on the 2nd December 1939. On the 22nd February 1940, the mother Mrs. Norman Hunter took Annie out of the Blue Quill's school. Mrs. Hunter took the girl home where she remained for a time. On the 23rd April 1940, Norman Hunter called the Reverend Principal by phone from Spedden, N. Hunter, why his children had been sent home. He also informed the Reverend Principal that he wanted to place his children in the Blue Quill's school and that he was sending Annie and another child to the school by train from Spedden and that he wished Reverend Father Balter to meet them. This was done and Annie has since April 23rd 1940, been in the Blue Quill's Residential school.

The parents insisting that they wished to have their children baptized into the Roman Catholic faith, Reverend Father Balter baptized Annie on the 19th May 1940.

Annie Hunter is shown on the Edmonton Residential school roll as pupil No. 0198 and is now shown on the Blue Quill's Residential school roll as pupil No. 0312.

The situation in this case today is, that the parents refuse to sign the applications for their children into the Edmonton Residential school. They insist that after taking everything into consideration, including religious faith, they desire that Annie remain in the Blue Quill's Residential school and that she be brought up in the Roman Catholic faith.

Sir:

Reference your No. 110-0-10 of October 29th, last, re application for admission to Edmonton Residential School of Francis Jackson, Annie Hunter, Lillian Hunter, and George Breast, Indian children from the Saddle Lake Agency: I beg to say, that upon receipt of your letter, I wrote to Mr. W. K. Gullion, Indian Agent, and to Rev. J. F. Woodsworth, the Principal, regarding same.

When at Saddle Lake Agency during the latter part of November, I took the matter up with Agent Gullion, and succeeded in getting certain information, which I asked him to put in letter form, copies of which I attach hereto.

Re Annie Hunter: Agent Gullion, Mr. J.H. Boorse, Farming Instructor, (who is now in charge of the Agency), and myself called at the Blue Quills School in St. Paul: The Principal stated that he had refused her father's request to admit her, but that she had been left at the School. Later an application was signed by the father; this was witnessed by two Indians from Saddle Lake. At a later date the mother took her home, and shortly afterwards the father called the Principal on the phone, and insisted that he take her back. He sent her by train to St. Paul, where she was met, and brought to the School, where she now is. I do not believe Norman Hunter, her father, will ever send her back to Edmonton School. The Agent had no reasons to give for not referring this case to the Department at once -- or at least sooner. I might add that I found the application had been filed away at the Agency Office.

Re Francis Jackson: This boy, I am told, is at the Edmonton School, but the father refuses to sign the application for admission.

Re Lillian Hunter: daughter of Cleophas Hunter; This Girl is also at Edmonton School, and the father refuses to sign the application.

Re George Breast: Agent Gullion's letter explains this case.

When discussing the matter with Agent Gullion, he made the following remarks:

Woodsworth visiting the Reserve for recruiting purposes. In some cases I later receive from the Principal a Physical Examination form, duly completed and signed by the Doctor, but the application for admission form merely gives the child's name and age -- not the parent's name and Treaty number. I presume these are sent to me to be completed, and for the signature of the parents. This I usually obtain when I visit the Reserve, and have found out who the parents are," -- Mr. Gullion might have added, "When I don't forget!" -- Mr. Gullion then continued: "In some cases the parents refuse to sign, saying they might do so later, if the child likes it at the School. The more I insist, the more stubborn they become in refusing to sign."

I might say that I saw a couple of these uncompleted forms at the Agency office. In my opinion, Rev. Mr. Woodsworth does not do his full part in this respect, and it is sometimes a puzzle for the Agent to know who the parents are. For example, Annie and Lillian Hunter, mentioned above: When I first mentioned this matter to the Agent, he stated they were sisters, Norman Hunter's children. When at Blue Quills School, Annie told me Lillian was her niece.

I submit, that before accepting a child into his School, Rev. Woodsworth should have the application form filled in and signed by the parents: I appreciate the Agent's difficulty in having these applications signed months afterwards, by parents who are: (1) Indifferent as regards their children's education; (2) Who do not favour the Edmonton School for various reasons, as stated in the Agent's letters, No. 95 of February 15th and November 25th, 1940.

Dear Sir;

I have your letter of 10th Inst. No. II5-I-IO, in regard to the children of Lawrence Hunter of Saddle Lake.

I may say that the boy Ernest was admitted to this school March 25th 1935 at the age of 10 years. It will be seen that this was a late age for a child to make a start at school having no knowledge of English or school life. It will also be noted that March is drawing toward the end of the school year and little could be expected of that term. Thus he has been in school not more than four years. I note also by the records that in the fall of 1936 the boy was a month and a half late in returning to school. Again in 1937 he was late. It will thus be seen that the parent was not extremely anxious for the education of his son. In spite of all this this he was in Grade III. Of course this year he did not return to school. I went personally to the reserve for the children and the Agent and myself did our best to get them back. The statement that he can neither add nor write is quite incorrect. It is an old excuse for parents who wish to have a case against the school, but I may say I have no apology for my teachers, or the academic standing of this school. The recent report of Mr. Scott the public school Inspector is no doubt in your hands, and his estimate of our school work should be of some value. I may say that most of the children of Lawrence have been in
this school, and have been as a rule very dull and stupid as far as class room work is concerned. Lawrence himself and his brothers and sisters have also been in the school, so I knew pretty much what to expect. Most of them as stated have been dull at books, but have otherwise been of little trouble. From past experience I am quite sure that the boy could be a perfect example of ignorance and stupidity if the occasion required. You ask about other reasons; it is partly a case of mind poisoning. Two or three people on this reserve are trying to be objectionable in regard to this school and this is one of the reactions. Mrs. Ralph Steinhauer, whose letter about this school was some time ago referred to Mr. Inspector Schmidt, has had some influence on the reserve. But little beyond a few malcontents.

I would like to maintain that this Saddle Lake difficulty has been dreadfully overemphasized. I am in constant touch with the people from there, and most of them are as friendly as ever. Lawrence is just sane, and has an idea that he will get something more elsewhere. It would be a serious mistake in the interests of this school, at this time, to give in to Lawrence in the matter of sending his children to Onion Lake. It would merely create more competition and add to the confusion which now exists in the minds of some of these people.

In talking the matter over with the recent Agent, Mr. Gullion he was of the opinion that compulsion might be used in the case of Lawrence to some advantage, and in my letter to The Department of December 4th I suggested this. I am still of the opinion that it would harm no one, and do a lot of good to have
these children brought in to this school as soon as possible. It would clear up much incipient stubbornness.

In my letter of Dec. 4th I gave the Department a list of a number of children who have not returned to school. To date none of these have been returned. I would greatly appreciate the cooperation of the Department in securing the attendance of those children who are already registered at the school. In the quarterly report recently sent forward the Department will note the cases. I believe a firm attitude in regard to attendance of pupils from this reserve would be of value in every way.

In regard to the little girl Caroline. On our Roll it is not Caroline but Jessie. Pupil No. 0202. This child came in after Xmas 1936 and is now in Grade II.

I trust this somewhat lengthy letter will be of some value to the Department in regard to the Saddle Lake situation. As stated I trust the Department will not consider the transfer of these children to another school.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]
Principal.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of the 10th instant with reference to Ernest Hunter, No. 182, and Jessie Hunter, No. 0202, of the Edmonton Indian Residential School, whose parents refused to return them to the school upon the expiration of their leave last summer.

Following the receipt of your letter we wrote to the Principal of the Edmonton School and it appears that there is no reason why Hunter should complain about the progress of his children.

Very careful consideration has been given to all sides of this case and it has been decided that these children should be returned immediately to the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

As you are aware, Subsection 6 of Section 10 of the Indian Act provides that every member of the R.C.M.P. shall be a truant officer to carry out the sections of the Indian Act.

I also direct your attention to Subsection 4 of Section 10. A member of the R.C.M.P. should be requested to notify Hunter that his children must be returned to the Edmonton School at once. If, after three days, Hunter has not complied the R.C.M.P. may arrest the children without a warrant and convey them to the Edmonton School.

Mr. J.H. Boorse,
Acting Indian Agent,
Saddle Lake, Alta.
Please let me know when action has been taken to carry out the instructions contained in this letter.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Your letter No. II0-0-10 of 17th Inst., to hand today. You request information in regard to the matter dealt with in paragraph one of the letter signed by Mr. Phalan of January 24th 1941.

I may say that I answered this letter on January 30th 1941. The matter dealt with the cases of Mary Steinhauer and Rema Bull. I can only quote the contents of my letter of January 30th.

"In regard to Mary Steinhauer No. 0113. In the September quarter I requested that this girl be allowed to continue her time at school. The Department allowed the grant for that quarter and made no comment on my request, so I presumed the request had been granted. This was the only case where I have made a request for continued attendance. Both the mother and the girl herself wish to be continued. I trust my request will be granted."

"In regard to Rema Bull. In your letter of December 6th you are dealing with the same misunderstanding regarding the daughter of Alex Bull of Sarcee. This girl is from Saddle Lake and has nothing to do with your letter of December 6th. Again see your letter of Oct. 29/40 and my reply of December 4th 1940."

I trust Mr. Hoey that we will be able to get this Rema Bull case straightened out. The girl was not discharged and apparently she has been confused in the mind of the Department with a Bull girl living at Sarcee, who was never at the school, but whose father made application for her admittance, which request was not granted by the Department.

If correspondence in regard to this matter cannot be located I shall be glad to forward my file on the matter.

I would be glad if you would let me know if this letter clears up the subject in question.

Yours Very Truly,

J.F. Woodsworth,

Reverend Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of the 21st instant with reference to two pupils of the Edmonton Residential School.

I note that you quote the contents of your letter of January 30, 1941. Our records do not indicate that this letter reached the Department.

No. 0113, Mary Steinhauer of Saddle Lake -- entered October 18, 1929, at age of 7 years. She is now 17\(\frac{1}{2}\) years of age. On February 23, 1940, we advised you that she was over 16 years of age and in June, 1940, you agreed to her discharge. A certificate of honourable discharge was forwarded for her on February 28, 1940. We cannot find any record of your having applied for her to remain in the Edmonton School for another year. However, as you consider it advisable to keep her grant will be allowed for her until June 30, 1941. You should advise me on that date whether you intend to discharge her or you wish her to stay for a further period. In the latter event your reasons for so desiring should be stated.

No. 0207, Rema Bull of Saddle Lake -- entered September 1, 1937, at the age of 13. She is now 17 years of age. Grant will also be allowed for her until June 30, 1941, at which time she should be discharged unless you wish her to remain. In the latter event you should give explicit reasons for so desiring.

Sir-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter of the 7th instant enclosing letters received by the Department from Mrs Joe Gouchier, Peers, Alta.

In reply I beg to report that on July 9th, 1941, I received a letter from Mrs Gouchier making the same request, I replied to her letter and stated that both of the children must return to the Youville Residential School at the end of the holidays.

Peers is approximately 135 miles from Edmonton on the Jasper Highway and it is very doubtful if these children will return to school unless an escort is sent to bring them back. The Department will no doubt recall that it was necessary to have these children escorted by the R.C.M.P. Police when they were placed in the Youville School in September 1935, from Malboro, Alta. 144 miles West of Edmonton.

Regarding Mrs Gouchier's claim in her letter dated August 1st, 1941 that her eldest daughter died from a fall when she was cleaning windows, this is not correct, her daughter Bessie age 8 years was admitted into the T.B. Wing in the Edmonton General Hospital on June 9th, 1938 and died in the T.B. Wing on March 21st, 1941. The parents were away at Peers and I was unable to get word to them and I had the child buried in the R.C. Cemetery at Winterburn.

In view of the fact that three of Mrs Gouchier's neighbours have stated that she keeps a good home and is quite able to care for the two children I would recommend that they be allowed to stay home and attend the local school, with the understanding that Mrs Gouchier pays all school taxes and any other expenses. Mrs Gouchier informed me in her letter dated July 5th, 1941 that she was receiving $79.00 per month from the Dependents Allowance Board since her husband enlisted in the Army. This being the case I see no reason why part of this money should not be used to educate the two children and save the Department a considerable amount of money.

Respectfully submitted,

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

G. C. Leight,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo with reference to Ben Peacock and Percy Lapotac.

Ben Peacock was admitted to the Youville Residential School on August 19, 1936, and remained in that institution until June 30 last at which time he was allowed home on holidays. He did not return to the Youville School on the expiry of his leave. In view of the information just given the Department is not prepared to approve his admission to the Edmonton Residential School. You should make arrangements for his immediate return to the Youville Residential School.

Careful consideration has been given to your report on the application for the admission of Percy Lapotac. It is extremely doubtful if he is eligible for admission to the Edmonton School on religious grounds. However, the Department is not prepared to make a definite decision in this matter at the present time. As the boy is only 6 years of age, and in view of the difficulty that has arisen regarding his religious status, he should be returned to his guardian immediately. It would be interesting to know when his parents died and on whose authority Lapotac became the guardian of the boy.

Leaving ten orphan children, these children with the exception of the eldest girl were placed in the Youville Indian Residential school until suitable homes could be found for them, three of the children have since died and the other seven have been adopted by members of the Enoch Band, Percy Cowan being adopted by James Lapotac.

Extract from Inspector Schmidt's report on the Edmonton Indian Residential School dated February 10, 1942.

The question of admission to this school has, in the past, caused a little dissatisfaction to Mr. W.E. Gullion, the ex-Indian Agent at Saddle Lake, and I am sorry to say that from remarks made by Agent W.F.B. Pugh, recently, he also is not satisfied. The point is this: Children are brought, or sent from their reserves on the Saddle Lake Agency, to the School, or to the School van, either on the reserve or in a neighbouring village, where they are gathered after the holidays. In some cases the parents bring the child, but the application for admission form is not signed. Later, the Principal has the child examined at the School by the Doctor, and if physically fit, sends the application forms to the Indian Agent at Saddle Lake to have them signed by the parents and approved by himself, as Agent. It may be several weeks, or even months, before the Agent can contact the parents, and there have been cases where -- as Mr. Agent Gullion stated in correspondence -- the parents have refused to sign. What the Agent asks is, that the Principal himself get the application signed by the parents. No doubt the resident missionary at Goodfish (Whitefish) Lake Reserve would assist in having these forms signed by the parents, and witnessed, before the child is taken to the school by someone other than the parent or guardian.
Copy sent to Mr. Woodsworth

Ottawa,
February 28, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your report regarding your recent visit to the Edmonton Residential School in which you mention that there has been some delay in securing application forms for pupils admitted to the Edmonton Residential School, due to the fact that the children were taken from the reserve before the application forms were signed.

I should appreciate it if you would arrange to have an interview with Indian Agent Pugh and Rev. Mr. Woodsworth before the beginning of the next school year. All of you are familiar with local conditions and I feel that you are the best qualified to fully discuss the matter and decide what action should be taken in the best interests of all parties concerned. All of you are aware that the Department requires an application form and certificate of health for each pupil admitted to a residential school and, at the same time, it is expected that as far as possible the Indian Agent should know what pupils are being sent to a residential school before they are placed in that institution. This requirement is due to the fact that he must certify the application form and in doing so he certifies to the statements made on it.

A copy of this letter is being sent to Rev. Mr. Woodsworth.

Yours truly,

Mr. C.P. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alta.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir

I am in receipt of your letter of Feb. 14th file H.110-0-23 dealing with the matter of supervision of the leisure time of the boys, being the outcome of our previous correspondence regarding the death of Joe Stamp.

I have taken this matter up and have arranged with one of the senior boys, Hector Jackson, who is about 17 years of age, to have as his duties outside of classroom hours, the direct supervision of the smaller boys. I have gone into this matter very thoroughly with the members of my staff, also with the boys themselves, and I think that this is possibly the best arrangement that we can make.

I have specified to Hector the various points of danger, such as around the machinery, around the stock yard when the bull might be out, the railway tracks and other places where there might be possible danger. It is Hector's duty to not only be there but to play with the boys which will give them, I think, the best type of supervision, he being an Indian lad from one of our best Indian families and one of our most trusted boys.

You might let me know what you think of this arrangement.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal.
Ottawa,
March 13, 1942.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant in which you state that you have arranged to have Hector Jackson supervise the boys outside of classroom hours. In your letter you state that Hector Jackson is 17 years of age. On the December quarter return of the Edmonton School Jackson is shown as 15 years of age. If the information on the December quarter return is correct, I am inclined to feel that Jackson is too young to handle the duties assigned to him. On the other hand, if his correct age is 17 this information should have been shown on the quarterly return as, in that event, he would have reached the age for discharge. I should appreciate hearing further from you regarding this boy.

Yours truly,

Dept. Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of March 13th, in further reference to Hector Jackson, I may say at the time of writing, the age on the December Quarter did not enter into my mind. I am quite free to admit these ages are not always correct. In some cases the ages given by the parents when a child is admitted is not always absolutely correct. In the course of a number of years, in copying the New Quarterly from the old one, it is quite possible the ages vary considerably.

It was my definite thought in regard to Hector Jackson when he left school last summer, that he had not attained his 16th birthday. It was his wish as well as that of his parents, that he return to school to finish up his work during the following year. However owing to the fact that he was alone with considerable farm work, the boy did not return to school until recently.

The mother returned with the boy and the matter of his age came up in our conversation, and I was somewhat surprised when she told me that he was actually 17 years old. The request of the parents and also the boy is that he remain in school and get his Diploma. My request is that the boy remain in school until end of September when he will be given considerable work to do on the farm; this is also the wish of his parents. In the mean time he is part-time in classroom and other times attending to duties assigned to him.

I trust this explanation is satisfactory to the Department, and that my request regarding the boy be granted.

Yours truly,

J.F. Woodsworth,
Principal

At present the boy is doing good work in caring for the small boys.

J.F.W.
Ottawa,
March 24, 1942.

Yours truly,

May 13, 1942.

Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Some weeks ago I was in receipt of a letter from Mr. Laight of the Edmonton Agency regarding the pupils who were up for discharge or otherwise at the end of June 1942.

Re Matthew Wesley, pupil No. 170 from the Babine Agency - I recently had a letter from Mr. Mallinson regarding the B.C. children. It is now a good many years since they came here and there has been a good deal of pressure brought to bear upon Mr. Mallinson by the parents for their discharge. I feel from the human standpoint that it is hardly fair to keep them longer from contact with their parents and with their native surroundings, and I am therefore, requesting that all of the B.C. children, with the exception of Matthew Wesley, be discharged and sent home.

Matthew is one of the best boys we have had in the school - there has never been any problem in regard to discipline or conduct and he has the capacity for development along either academic or vocational lines. As pointed out by Mr. Mallinson, he has no home in Hazelton and the other day in talking to the boy himself he said that he would rather remain at the school than go to his home. I would therefore, like to retain Matthew Wesley as a pupil of this school for at least another year, and endeavor to give him special instructions along vocational lines, particularly along the line of manual training, in which the Department has specialized.

The other B.C. children's names are as follows:

- Willis Morgan - Pupil No. 189
- Richard Morgan - Pupil No. 191
- Matilda Gungoat - Pupil No. 0158
- Elsie Green - Pupil No. 0165
- Elsie Turley - Pupil No. 0189

I may also say that particularly during the holidays these girls as they grow older present quite a moral problem for the school in the line of supervision and I think that they should go home.
Ottawa,
May 18, 1942.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, with reference to discharging pupils from the Edmonton Residential School at the end of June.

The discharge of pupils numbered as follows is approved:

| No. | No. | No. |
|-----|-----|-----|
| 180 | 200 | 0173 |
| 189 | 0158 | 0189 |
| 191 | 0165 | 0207 |

Pupils numbered 172, 183, 199, 0109 and 0133 are 16 years of age or over and in the case of the last two mentioned it is noted that they are 18 years of age. There is no authority in the Indian Act by which we can approve children remaining in a residential school after they reach the age of 16 years. Besides, no difficulty should be experienced in these young people obtaining work this year. As a matter of fact we have had dozens of offers of positions for Indian pupils in Eastern Canada and many of these we were unable to fill. Taking these facts into consideration, the Department cannot see its way clear to approve these pupils remaining in the Edmonton School for a further period. Consequently, they should also be discharged at the end of June.

The quarterly return shows that Matthew Wesley is 15 years of age and the Department approves his remaining in the Edmonton School until June 30, 1943.

Rev. J.F. Woodsworth,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Edmonton, Alta.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

The possibility of using the Youville School and the Edmonton School for Japanese has probably received the attention of the Indians in your Agency. However, subsequent developments indicate definitely that these buildings will not be used for the purpose originally suggested and consequently both schools should continue during the academic year 1942-43. Rumours that have been current will no doubt have an unsettling effect on the Indians and, as a result, many of them may not wish to return their children to whichever school these children formerly attended. The Department, therefore, desires that you will co-operate fully with the Principal of either of the above schools in returning children. I have no doubt that you have done this in the past, but I feel that an extra effort will probably be required this year.

I should appreciate your advising me later regarding the action you have taken in returning to the schools mentioned pupils who were enrolled during the past academic year and are eligible to return, as well as the assistance you give to the Principals to recruit new pupils who reach school age.

Yours truly,

Sent to the following Agents:

Mr. G.C. Laight, Winterburn.

Sir:—

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your 110-1-10 of the 17th Ult: regarding the return of pupils to the Edmonton Indian Residential School and in reply beg to report that as soon as I knew for certain that this school was not being closed I immediately informed all Protestant Indians at this Agency of the fact, and informed them that their children would be returning to the Edmonton School on the 1st September.

On receipt of your letter I requested the Farming Instructor to inform all Protestant parents that their children would be leaving for Edmonton on the 1.55 P.M. train on the 1st September. I posted notices in the Indian waiting room and informed all protestant Indians I came in contact with.

I returned 20 old pupils, 3 new ones, from Hobbema; there are 4 pupils who spent their vacation at the Sarcee reserve, who will return direct from there, 2 boys given permission to remain out for a further two weeks and there are two new children going when the above two boys return. This accounts for all the possible pupils for this school this term.

August 28th 1943.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

Yesterday I visited the Indian Agent and the United Church Missionary, Mr. Law, at Hobbema. While there I discussed various problems with both these gentlemen. Two cases in particular were somewhat disturbing; first that of the two girls of James Louis who are now registered in this school—Pupils Nos. 0245 and 0246 Mary and Lily Louis both of whom have been in this school for two years. I believe that an application has already been forwarded to the Department signed by Jim Louis and probably written by Father Moulin asking that these girls be taken from this school and placed in the Erminskin school. This has been done under the pretext that Jim has turned R.C. and wishes the girls transferred. If you will note, the applications were made out in good faith and signed by the father as a Protestant. From the information gathered I learn that Father Moulin has brought great pressure to bear upon this family, by constant coaxings and has evidently at last persuaded the father to sign the document forwarded to you. As Principal of this school and as a Protestant I feel this is a flagrant violation, at least in spirit, of the effort of the Department to have Protestant children attend Protestant schools and visa versa. I protest most emphatically against this action of Father Moulin. I have arranged for the children to return to school from Hobbema on Thursday Sept. 2nd, in accordance with your letter of June 15th 1943, No.150-37. It seems too bad that plans made to carry out Departmental wishes should be thwarted by an effort on the part of this Father Moulin to disrupt the efforts of cooperation which should exist at this time. I would like a communication to be in the hands of Mr. Indian Agent, Col Louis by Next Thursday authorizing the return of these two girls. I may say that Jim Louis—or Lightning—is a graduate of this school.

Another matter was brought to my attention, also another case of the activities of Father Moulin. The Department is also in receipt of a letter regarding this matter. Some two or three years ago I married, at Hobbema, Emily Littlepoplar to John Strongman of the Montana Band. Their child was baptized by Mr. Law. Since then Father Moulin has constantly pestered the family to have the child re-baptized as a R.C. Much against the protests of the mother whom the priest ignores. The action of Father Moulin has caused deep resentment among the Protestant people of this community. And yet, as Indians usually are, they seem unable to withstand the subtle approach he makes. As a measure of decency I do not think these unwelcome and incessant aggressions on the part of Father Moulin should be allowed to continue. No doubt Father Moulin thinks that any form of aggression is justified according to his conception of religion but I wish to enter my protest against the way he is interfering with our Protestant community.

Yours Truly,

J.F. Woodsworth
Principal.

Attention please, Mr. P. Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Will you please advise me on the following:
Bella Marie Alexis, age 10 years, daughter of Jee and Mrs. Alexis, No.48 Alexis Band, has been brought up and living with her grandparents Tom and Mrs. Rain, No.69 Paul's Band since she was six months old. Tom Rain and his wife are Protestants and the child has been brought up as a Protestant. The father is a Roman Catholic and the mother was a Protestant until she married Jee Alexis. The child is paid Annuity under Tom Rain's Ticket No.69 Paul's Band.

This year the child was ordered into school and her grandfather sent her to the Edmonton Residential School, her admission into this school has been approved by the Department. The child having been brought up as Protestant by her grandparents since she was six months old I have always considered her to be a Protestant, I was unaware that the child had been baptised into the Roman Catholic Faith.

The mother Mrs. Jee Alexis has now asked that the child be transferred from the Edmonton Residential School to the Youville Residential School, I have received a Certificate of Baptism showing that Bella Marie Alexis was baptised at the Roman Catholic Mission at Lac-Ste-Anne on the 17th of September 1933, she was born on the 9th of August 1933.

Since Mrs. Alexis requested that the child be transferred I have interviewed the grandfather who informs me that Bella was given to him and his wife by her parents when she was six months old, that they have always considered her to be their own child and had brought her up as a Protestant, and that it was his wish that Bella attend the Edmonton Residential School.

If I may be permitted, I would recommend that due to the fact that the parents have had nothing to do with the bringing up of this child since she was six months old that the grandparents request be granted and the child remain in the Edmonton Residential School.

Respectfully submitted,

G. G. Laight,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa,
January 5, 1944.

Mr. G.C. Laight, Indian Agent, Winterburn, Alta.

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, with reference to Bella Marie Alexis. The information given in your letter was not supplied when application was made for her admission to the Edmonton Residential School. If you had supplied this information at that time the application would not have been immediately approved.

As no legal adoption has been made by the grandparents the Department is inclined to feel that the wishes of the parents should be recognized. However, before making a final decision on what school this child should be placed in we wish to see the statement signed by both parents stating the school in which they desire their child educated and also agreeing to allow the child to remain in that particular school until she reaches the age of 16 years.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

fall however the father refused to return them to school because as he

take some action in this matter as the Indian Agent at Hobbema would

Missionary from Hobbema last week, he informed me that these two
girls were now attending the Roman Catholic Indian School at Hobbema.

I beg to report that I have received a complaint from Rev. J. F. Woodsworth, Principal of the Edmonton Indian Residential School regarding the conduct of Pupil No. 0258, Lettie Rain, Age 14 years. I am informed by the Principal that this girl is very insulting to the teachers and matron of the school, that she has a very bad influence on the other children and that recently she tried to get three other girls to run away from the school. Mr. Woodsworth states that he has punished Lottie but that it has no effect and he has asked that she be expelled from the school.

Personally I am not in favor of the girl being expelled, in my opinion this form of punishment does not have the desired effect upon an Indian, it only encourages other pupils to misbehave themselves hoping that they will be expelled from school for the same reason. I would recommend that Lettie Rain be placed in the Home of Sisters of Our Lady of Charity Good Shepherd, 11409-96th Street, Edmonton, Alberta., for a period of four months from May 1st until September 30th 1944 then returned to the school, this would be more punishment than expelling her from school, as she would not be able to go home for the summer holidays, it would also be a lesson to the other pupils of the school. The cost of keeping her in the Home of the Good Shepherd would be $15.00 per month.

G. G. Laight,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
March 29, 1944.

Mr. G.C. Laight, Indian Agent, Winterburn, Alta.

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, with reference to Lottie Rain, No. 0256, Edmonton Indian Residential School. Provided the Principal of the Edmonton School does not object, the Department is in favour of your suggestion that this girl be placed for a period of four months in the institution that you mention. We will be responsible for her maintenance at the rate of $15 a month. At the end of the four-month period she can be returned to the Edmonton School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Re: Complaint Alkie Simon

With reference to your letter of September 28th, in which you enclosed an extract from a letter supposedly written by one Alexis Simon, #114, Paul's Band, I beg to advise that a few days after I received your letter I had the man into my office & had a talk with him. He said that he did not write the letter himself but that the letter was the outcome of a meeting which several of the Indians had had on the reserve with some white man.

I asked him if he had any specific charges to make against the doctor, but he had nothing definite, only generalities. He said however that some of the other Indians had complaints to make, so I told him that I would be at the reserve headquarters on October 12th & would be prepared to listen to any complaints & for him to let the other Indians know that I would be there.

When I got there in the morning, there were no Indians around & after waiting for a time I went around & visited several homes, in fact all the homes where there was anyone staying. I then came back to headquarters & found Alexis & Peter Burnstick waiting for me, but no others. I had a talk with them & they claimed that Dr. Conroy did not give the Indians enough attention and that they were not at all satisfied with the way he examined the sick & mentioned several cases where he had been neglectful & where the patients had died, but these were all old cases & nothing recent. While visiting at the different homes & enquiring after the sick, I found that in every case the Indians were not satisfied with the service they were getting. They seemed to think that if an Indian had a toothache, it was up to the doctor to come out there forty or forty five miles & do what was necessary. I explained to them that it would be a whole lot easier for the Indian to go into Edmonton.
Edmonton to see the doctor than it was for the doctor to come out to the reserve, unless it was in the case of an accident or some serious illness, but they seemed to have the impression that the doctor should come to them.

I didn't at all like their attitude & it seems to me that they are being stirred up by someone on the outside. Everything seemed to be wrong with the way their affairs had been administered and I think they really have been allowed to get out of hand and have been allowed to do pretty much as they pleased, with the result that they have done practically no work and have made up their minds that it is up to the government to look after them.

I arranged for another meeting on Thursday the 26th & had a much better attendance of Indians then. They had just got through threshing their crop & it was pitifully small.

Previous to the meeting, I had had the doctor visit the reserve & go around the homes with the farming instructor & check on any cases of sickness. This would appear to have pleased them for there were no more complaints about lack of attention and they told me they were glad I had the doctor visit them & he had listened to them & had paid more attention to what they had to tell them.

In a great many cases it is wasted effort for the doctor to go out to visit them, for, after visiting them & telling them what to do, they will not follow his instructions & will not go to the hospital.

I think myself that if the doctor were to make periodic general visits to the reserve & go around the homes with myself or the farming instructor, a much better feeling could be established amongst these Indians & I would recommend that this be done about once a month, weather permitting.

I hardly think there will be any more kicks.

J.T.Faunt,
Acting Indian Agent.
Duffield Alberta
September 20th 1944

Gentlemen:

Would you please inform me at what age our children must start school, is it compulsory to let our children be taken away from us to a boarding school at so young an age as 7 years. I have one child of 7 years that the agent and doctor insist I must let go, or the R.C.M.P. will get after me, this appears to be very unfair as my child cannot do anything for itself, why are not allowed a day school on the reserve for our younger children up to 10 years of age, this would be much better for our children, and more acceptable to us parents, surely we are entitled to some rights.

I volunteered for service in this war, and have a discharged badge No. 6547, yet I have no right to expect fair treatment, nor right to express any opinion, just do as I am ordered, this treatment is creating a very discontented feeling among a lot of us.

We have also a strong resentment against the way our sick are being treated, we are not allowed to have any other doctor than Dr. Conroy of Edmonton, but when he is needed he comes when it suits him, sometimes 2 or 3 days late, and when he does consent to come he often does not get out of his car, just looks through the window, and says "there's nothing the matter with you."
away he goes, but I bet he don't forget to put in his expenses for the trip; it is very unsatisfactory, and certainly not fair to us, we get no examination, or very seldom, we are only Indians so why bother, the sooner we are extinct the better that's the attitude, why cannot we have our own choice of doctor its too bad we are such a bother to the government, but if agents and doctors were given to understand we are human beings and must be treated as such, there would be a better understanding between us and the White man, some of us do try and make good, but we are all treated the same, as if we are a nuisance.

I regret having any complaint to make but many of us feel these two subjects could be dealt with in a better way.

Wish for a better understanding and fair treatment

respectfully yours,

Algie Simon
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

This child is 11 years old & is not very strong & am satisfied that she is much better out of school, but if you would consider an application to put her in the protestant school I can obtain one & send it in, though, as I have already said Mr Woodsworth does not want her.

Dear Mr. Nathaniel Sunday,

I'm going to tell you that the last letter Martha wrote was all lies. But it was I that wrote the letter for her. The Duffield girls never do any dirty tricks to her. Also the ladies try their very best to do good things to us all; I just write what she say to me in the letter. I hope you will forget all about that lie. It is not true. By the way she thinks the girls are getting after her when they tease her. But will never do that again telling lies in the letter. I'm telling you the true. But I don't remember when did I saucy talk about the ladies in this letter. Because they are trying to be good us, and they sure work hard for the children. That was the first letter we told a lie. If she didn't tell me to write that I wouldn't want to tell a lie. I was surprised when she told me to tell on the Duffield girls. Because she never says anything about the girls, when I write for her. I really don't remember when did the girls say anything to her. Maybe she missed understood them. That's all I'm saying for now.

So goodbye

From (signed) Leslie Jackson

I'm very sorry I won't every do that again. Please forgive me all this dirty lies. (signed) Leslie Jackson.

Dear Sir,

Dr. Woodsworth gave me your letter, which he received yesterday.

I was surprised, as I have never heard of anyone hurting or getting after Martha.

I questioned Martha and she says the girls are not bad to her.

As you know Martha cannot write a letter herself, and she got one of the Good Fish Lake girls to write it for her. I think this girl must or had a mean streak in her, and wanted to make trouble for Martha or the school. ("there is no truth in it").

I am looking after the girls myself, and know fairly well what is going on. So you need not worry over Martha.

We have had one of the best winters in the school. No sickness and all pupils passed their X-ray without any active T.B. among them, so we have something to be thankful for.

To the Principal of the School,

Dear Preacher,

I am writing to you about Martha. I heard that she is being treated meanly by the girls and so I do not want that girl to be treated badly. When I thought of putting her to school there I wouldn't have liked it. She was a bad girl, but I know myself that she is a good girl cause I've brought her up myself, and so I'm just going to take her out of school when she comes for her holidays. She won't be there any more. I thought of putting 2 more girls to school but I am not sending them. We have a district school here 2 miles from our place and so I'm sending them there. Maybe the ladies don't care and watch the girls the way they treat her, and so I am going to tell you about myself. I was in school at Red Deer Ina. School. My father used to tell me something to try and be good in school, and as I tried to do what my father used to tell me, I wasn't bad or mean in school, and the children were bad to me, no matter when I never said anything they used to hit me lots of times. And lots of times too they would fight me 2 or 3 getting after me, and from there the way they hit me I used to have pains all over, and not strong, and so that's why I don't like this the way the other girls treat her, cause she won't be strong enough, and so I'm just going to take her out of school that what I promise you. I am not doing this behind your back that way I am meaning this and telling you that I am going to do. That's all I could tell you.

Yours truly

March 21, 1945

The Secretary  
Indian Affairs Branch  
Department of Mines and Resources  
Ottawa, Ontario

Dear Sir:

I enclose, herewith, a copy of a letter I received from Nathaniel Sumay of Saddle Lake, Alberta. Nathaniel is a Treaty Indian or the Saddle Lake Agency and has a daughter Martha in this school. As you will note, Nathaniel writes regarding the treatment of his daughter and states very emphatically that he does not intend to send the girl back to school after the holidays. I also enclose a letter which Miss McDonald, our Matron, wrote Nathaniel in reply to his letter. We also have evidence that this story is entirely false, as you will see by the enclosed letter signed by Elsie Jackson.

This whole thing may appear to be very trivial and something of a tempest in a tea-pot to be writing to the Department about. But I feel that it involves a matter that should receive the attention of the Department. It would hardly seem reasonable that the Department would allow a parent off hand to decide whether his child should attend school or not particularly after she has been admitted by the Department. There have been a number of such cases during the past few months where the parents for little or no reason whatever are keeping their children out of school. There are at present eight children from the Saddle Lake Agency who are still out of school, and the agent Mr. Pugh finds it impossible to get them back. As far as I know there is at present time no adequate reason why they should not be in school. I believe that Mr. Pugh has done all in his power outside of police action to get these children back. I am sure that it would be greatly appreciated if the Department would strengthen the hand of the Indian Agent in dealing with this and similar cases.

I am writing this letter to you early in the year, long before holidays so that next fall when school opens some of these problems of attendance may be well in hand, and we may not experience some of the difficulties which we have experienced during the last few years.

In spite of the apparent triviality of this matter I trust the Department will give this letter consideration.

Yours truly,

J.F. Woodsworth, Principal

Pupil No. 197 is recommended for discharge. He has been home on the reserve during the past year and is now 16 years of age. Pupil No. 0106 whom we thought might return last year is now married and living on the Hobbema Agency.

In regard to Pupils Nos. 0201 and 0205. These are two very capable and promising girls. Last year at the suggestion of the Department they took their Grade IX here at the school instead of attending Alberta College as was also suggested. I do not consider that they had a fair chance in their studies. I started the term with a good teacher who was interested in their work, but at Xmas time this teacher left and I was only able to secure a young woman as teacher without proper qualifications for teaching high school subjects. The result was that the girls did not try their exams. I would like to see these two girls repeat their year attending Alberta College. They themselves wish to return and their parents, I believe are also agreeable. I request that they remain at school, and that the Indian Affairs Branch pay their per capita and also an amount which will enable them to attend Alberta College. The school to assume part of the extra costs of attendance.

I may say that some years ago pupils from this school took high school work at this institution and did fairly good work. These are the first pupils since then who have been interested in advanced work. I trust that it will be possible to let them continue with their education.

Dear Mr. Faunt;

I have your letter re. matters concerning the June quarterly report. In regard to Sylvia Houle, I may say that I had this girl examined by the M.D. last April and immediately forwarded the application to the Indian agent at Saddle Lake. Since then I have had no information regarding the application form. I may say that this form is doubtless in the hands of the parents of this girl.

In regard to the pupils mentioned in the 2nd paragraph. Time and again I have taken this matter up with the Indian Agent at Saddle Lake. I have also written directly to the Indian Affairs Branch urging that some action be taken to have these children sent to school. I do not consider that I should apply for their discharge as most of them should be in school, and applying for discharge is merely an easy way of getting over a difficulty. I have pointed out to the Branch that every year there are a large number who are absent from this Agency, and who stay out without apparently any compulsion being applied on the part of the government authorities. If these children for any reason should not attend I would appreciate very much being informed of the reasons for non-attendance, but so far the only reasons advanced is that the parents will not send them in.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

With reference to your letter of July 19th regarding the June quarter return of the Edmonton Indian Residential School, I wrote to Mr. Woodsworth, sending him a copy of your letter & now have a reply from him, copy of which I am enclosing herewith.

I don't know what grounds Mr. Woodsworth may have for his complaint against the government authorities at the Saddle Lake Agency, but I do think it is too bad that the children concerned should be deprived of an education, if a little pressure applied in the proper place would get them to school.

When I came here about a year ago, I asked Mr. Woodsworth to furnish me with a copy of his quarterly return, but he said he had never been called upon to furnish one to the Agency & he did not feel that it was necessary. I contend however, that if I am supposed to supervise the school, I should have a copy of the returns & also that the returns for Ottawa should go through this office.

Mr. Woodsworth would now appear to be of the opinion that I should have a copy of the returns & suggests that he be furnished with a wide carriage typewriter, on which to make out these forms & others, requiring the use of a wide carriage machine.

If such a machine could be made available to Mr. Woodsworth I would recommend that it be furnished.

Stoney Indian Agency,
Morley, Alberta,
November 2nd, 1945.

Highlights of a Meeting held on
Stony Indian Reserve
Morley

Silas Abraham Wesley (Nordegg)

It was his first time at a meeting like this. The old people found they couldn't get along on the Reserve and they had been living in Nordegg since the first white man between 60 and 80 years. The boys were now growing up and trying to make a living for themselves.

He said that there were some old people in Nordegg and he wanted to get a permit for them to obtain extra rations.

The Indians of Nordegg wanted a school.

He wanted an extension of the trapping season so that they could get more fur. At present he would only take five marten and he wanted to take 12.

Mr. Allan At this Point Mr. Allan interjected. He took Silas Abraham's points from the last first.

He explained that the trapping regulations were made by the Province and he was surprised that the Indians were allowed to take any marten at all. If this was true Alberta was possibly the only province in the Dominion allowing an open season on marten because they were so scarce.

He advised Abraham that he was very fortunate in this regard and warned him to take only what he was allowed and to protect and see that the remainder of the marten were protected for the future of his own children as well as for the future of all trappers.

He explained that at present the Dominion Government has a man employed full time in Alberta re-stocking Indian trap lines. Today there are 950 trap line licenses issued whereas four years ago there were none. The department was trying to re-stock all Indian trap lines especially in isolated areas and to that end last year 55 live beaver had been transplanted from their own homes to new districts.

Mr. Allan said he was going to Banff immediately and while there would arrange for the transfer of live marten to re-stock trap lines and in an effort to protect the marten.

Regarding the day school for Nordegg Mr. Allan thought it was possible if the Indians lived close enough to the school and there were enough children to attend the school "But that is not, in my opinion, the proper way to approach the educational problem." In Nordegg there were only 9 or 10 children of school age and the Indian Residential School at Edmonton was not filled at present. Therefore it was quite possible for the Nordegg children to attend in Edmonton.

But, he said, if a Reserve is established at Nordegg the school and the youngsters are together. If the problem of the Reserve is solved the problem of the school and the youngsters is also solved. So far it has been impossible for the Department to make any arrangements with the provincial educational authorities - the Indians at Nordegg were living inside a forest Reserve and the province would not permit any school facilities in that location and thereby establish precedent.

In connection with the old people and the request for more rations Mr. Allan said that he would recommend to the
Superintendent General that any aged, infirm or sick should be paid an allowance from the Band Fund.
