Chief Peacock stated that he would like to talk about the children getting home from school for the Xmas holidays. He stated that for a long time, Xmas and New Years had been the greatest days for the Indians and they had brought the matter up as they wanted their children home for that time. They had expected to take the matter up with the inspector but he had not yet arrived. They had brought the matter up before and wanted a definite answer, yes or no. In regard to relief, the people had already got the habit of getting help and there was no reason why they could not have it when they had the money. The white people got help and had no money. He said they were promised that when they were hard-up they would get help. When the North part of the Reserve was sold, an agreement was made that help would be given when needed. In Mr. Hace's time they had shovelled snow off the road and got grub. At that time they had asked for $10.00 a head and in less than two weeks they got it. He said they wanted an answer yes or no; that the Agency had authority to give them help if they wanted to.

Mr. Faunt advised them that as regards the school, he had no authority to say the children could get out. He could make application to the Department and explain their wishes. As explained to the Council the previous day, this would set a precedent for other bands and reserves. Some of the people were scattered all over the bush country and the children would be scattered all over. The Department would have to take this into consideration as the same privilege would have to apply to all. Some of the children were not yet in for the fall term and if allowed out at Xmas they would probably not all be back by Spring. However, if they asked that he write the Department asking that the children be allowed out at Xmas, he would take the matter up with them.

It was moved by Jas. Peacock and seconded by Wm. Morin that Mr. Faunt write the Department and ask that the children be allowed out for a few days at Xmas. Passed unanimously.

J.J. Faunt,
Indian Agent.
With regard to the request that the children be allowed out of school for the Christmas holidays, I communicated directly with the Department & have received a reply to the effect that such holidays would not be allowed.

J.T. Raunt,
Indian Agent.

The Department finds it necessary to send back the December quarter return of the Edmonton Residential School. Both in your interest and in our own, we desire that these returns be absolutely accurate.

As you know, the per capita allowance is paid from the information given under the heading "Total number of days pupil in residence during the quarter". On reviewing the return we find in the case of pupil 211 that no grant is asked, but in the column under the heading "Remarks" you state "Now in school". If the pupil was in residence during any part of the December quarter, you are entitled to grant for that period. If the pupil was not in residence during the quarter, the statement "now in school" should not appear on the return, as this return covers the period October 1 to December 31, 1945. Any information shown on the return should refer to pupils during that particular quarter.

I might borrow the jeeps they have supplied to them for Indian work. My request for the jeep having merely turned down. This is the second time it has happened. Dear Mr. Thackeray:

I was indeed glad to receive your letter of September 22nd and particularly pleased to note that the son of my old friend, Bernard Thackeray, was engaged in missionary effort on one of our Indian reserves.

You refer in your letter to conditions confronting you on the reserve at Saddle Lake and to ways and means whereby conditions might be improved. I feel confident that you will believe me when I say that these and a number of such problems have been engaging the attention of the officials here and my own personal attention almost continuously during the last ten-year period. The advancement of the Indian population, as I see it, demands a great deal of self-sacrifice on the part of those engaged in the administration of Indian Affairs and an abundance of patience on the part of our white citizens and Indians alike.

You refer to the operation of Indian residential schools. We have, I may state, approximately $12,000,000.00 invested in these schools at the moment, and it is not likely that this Government or any Government that might succeed it, will cease the operation of these schools at any time in the immediate future. I am hopeful, however, that residential schools can become increasingly more up-to-date.

You refer to the half-day instruction given at such schools. In this connection, you will be glad to learn that the period of instruction is being gradually extended. Indian day school pupils, on the other hand, owing to the irregularity of attendance and the Indian's lack of interest in education of any kind, seldom receive more actual instruction than residential school pupils - the average attendance per annum seldom exceeding 60%. It is just possible, however, that the payment of family allowances may help us to correct this condition.

Reverend B. H. Thackeray,
SADDLE LAKE,
Alberta.

..... We work,
We work, as you know, in close cooperation with the church authorities in the operation of our schools. I have been wondering if it would be possible for you to summarize conditions at Saddle Lake from the educational standpoint and send forward your summary with any recommendation you may care to make, including your offer of the church building, to Doctor Dorey, Secretary of the Board of Home Missions. The problem at Saddle Lake, as I see it, is to establish an Indian day school without reducing the number now enrolled at the Edmonton residential school. In any event, if your recommendation is sent forward, it will, I feel sure, be carefully and sympathetically reviewed. It is unnecessary to add that I appreciate very fully your anxiousness to bring this matter to my personal attention. It is also unnecessary to add that I want you to feel free to communicate with me at any time.

Dear Mr. Thackeray:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of October 17th, in which you refer to your interview with Mr. Staley and to the fact that conditions at the Edmonton Indian residential school are steadily improving.

I was particularly interested in your reference to the jeep supplied by the department for the use of the Indian Agent and Farming Instructor. I have discussed this reference of yours with Inspector Gooderham, who is at this time visiting Ottawa. He has promised me that he will discuss the matter with the Agent immediately following his return to Alberta.

The Government has never at any time accepted responsibility for missionary effort on Indian reserves. We believe that it is in the best interests of the Indians, the Churches engaged in such effort and citizens generally that missionary effort should be completely detached from Government regulations and, of course, from dictation by Government officials. The position of the Government in this respect is, I feel sure, fully understood by the Churches. Indian Agency equipment, therefore, has never at any time been placed at the disposal of men engaged in missionary work, and, if the Catholic missionary at Saddle Lake has had the use of the automobile or the jeep for Church work, this use is wholly irregular and against departmental regulations. The Churches have always accepted a certain amount of responsibility for the recruiting of pupils on reserves and for their enrolment at residential schools.

Reverend B. H. Thackeray,
SADDLE LAKE,
Alberta.
When recruiting actually takes place, however, on a reserve, the visiting of homes by the principal of the school or by the missionary on the reserve might well be undertaken in cooperation with the Indian Agent or the Farming Instructor. In such cases, the use of Agency equipment would, of course, be quite legitimate. I am anxious, however, that in this regard there should be no discrimination. The Government of Canada, theoretically and in fact, represents the people of Canada, including all creeds and classes. It is of the utmost importance and in the interest of the Churches themselves that a spirit resulting in fair play and an equal opportunity should be in evidence on our reserves at all times.

Yours sincerely,

At approximately 7:30 P.M. on the 19th inst., a telephone call was received at this office from Mrs. Simon LAMBERTIN residing five miles east of Namao, Alta., to the effect that four Indian boys who had run away from the Indian School at St. Albert, were at her place, and one of them had his feet badly frozen.

Acting on instructions received from the R.C.O. in charge, Edmonton Detachment the writer accompanied by Sgt. Russellfield patrolled to the above noted residence per Police transport Code No. 2846.

On arrival the boys were found to be Henry HUNTER, Ralph WHITFORD, Billy WHITFORD, and Francis MARSHALL, the latter being the boy with the frozen feet. On being questioned the boys stated that they were all from the Indian Residential School, three miles east of St. Albert. They stated they ran away because they did not like being locked in at night.

Appropriate First Aid was administered to MARSHALL's frozen feet and patrol returned with the four boys to the Dr. Conell Indian Hospital in Edmonton, where MARSHALL was turned over to Dr. RICHEL for necessary treatment and hospitalization.

Patrol continued to the Indian Residential School with the remaining three boys, turning them over to Mr. STALEY, Principal, patrol then returning to Detachment.

Further action being unwarranted by this Detachment this file is being shown as concluded here. Extra copies attached for the information of the Department concerned.

"At approximately 7:30 p.m. on the 19th inst., a telephone call was received at this office from Mrs. Simon LAMOURLEUX residing five miles East of Namao, Alta. to the effect that four Indian boys who had run away from the Indian School at St. Albert, were at her place, and one of them had his feet badly frozen.

Acting on instructions received from the N.C.O. in Charge, Edmonton Detachment the writer accompanied by Cst. Hasselfield patrolled to the above noted residence per Police transport Code No. 2848.

On arrival the boys were found to be Henry Hunter, Ralph Whitford, Billy Whitford, and Francis Wahsatenau, the latter being the boy with the frozen feet. On being questioned the boys stated that they were all from the Indian Residential School, three miles East of St. Albert. They stated they ran away because they did not like being locked in at night.

Appropriate First Aid was administered to Wahsatenau's frozen feet and patrol returned with the four boys to the Dr. Camsell Indian Hospital in Edmonton, where Wahsatenau was turned over to Dr. Riopel for necessary treatment and hospitalization.

Patrol continued to the Indian Residential School with the remaining three boys, turning them over to Mr. Staley, Principal, patrol then returning to Detachment."

EDMONTON
ALBERTA

February 7th 1947.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of February 4th regarding the report of the R.C.M.P. in connection with the running away of four boys from this school and would say that the circumstances were pretty much as reported.

I would explain that January 19th was a Sunday and the weather being fine, the boys were all outside after lunch and their absence was not noticed until suppertime. The other boys were questioned but they claimed that they did not know where the four boys were, and intimated that they might be around some of the barns or in the pumphouse. These buildings were searched with no result and then one of the older boys volunteered the information that just after lunch he had seen the four heading eastward and that they were all wrapped up and it was his impression they were heading for home at Saddle Lake.

By this time it was seven o'clock and we immediately got on the phone and called a number of the people along the route the boys were likely to travel, asking them if they had seen anything of them.

While we were engaged in this, a telephone came in from the Mounted Police in Edmonton, telling us that they had a call from a point East of Namao, telling them that four boys from the Indian school had stopped in there and that one of them had his toes frozen.

Mr. Faunt, who answered the phone, told them that we had just been trying to locate the boys by phone and asked them if they would send a patrol out to bring the boys in, taking the boy with the frozen foot to the Indian Hospital and bringing the other three back here.

He then telephoned the Hospital and arranged for the immediate care of the boy and when the police brought him in, he was given immediate attention.

It was thought at one time that he might lose one of his toes, but this was not the case and in fact we are expecting his return to the school today, fully healed.

On questioning the boys on their return, it was found that the break had been planned several days ahead and that they had just been waiting for fine weather. The early part of that Sunday was
Was unusually fine, with the temperature up to 45°, so they just decided this was the day. Unfortunately however there was a sudden dip in the temperature and in a few hours the thermometer was registering -12° and it was more by luck than by good judgement that they had not got further from school and were able to find a place to stay, it having been their intention to keep away from houses and to sleep in a straw stack when they got tired, in which case they might very easily have been frozen to death, as the thermometer went below -30° that night.

There had been no trouble with any of the boys before this break and there has been none since. They said they got homesick and gave in to the urge to go home.

Yours very truly,

E.J. Stanley,
Principal.

We have your letter of the 19th ultimo with reference to a request for the transfer of Betsy Lightning, No. 0686 from the Ermineskin School to the Edmonton Residential School.

As you are probably aware, Betsy Lightning was admitted to the Ermineskin School in December, 1939 and the application form was signed by her father and stated that she was a Roman Catholic. The application form was approved by Indian Agent Lewis, who was in charge of the Hobbema agency at that time. It is noted that the parents now request that she be transferred to the Edmonton Residential School which is under United Church auspices.

At this time I feel it advisable to give a general statement concerning the Department's practice and indicating how our officers are guided when cases such as this arise.

The compulsory education clauses of the Indian Act read in part: "No Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic school or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school or a school conducted under Protestant auspices." The intention of this section is that an Indian child shall attend a school conducted under the auspices of the church with which the child and its parents are affiliated. The Department believes strict adherence to this rule is in the best interests of its wards.
Whenever there is doubt concerning the religion of an applicant for admission to an Indian residential school, Indian agents are instructed to make careful enquiries. The Department understands that the chief deciding factors in the determination of the religion of a child of tender years are the religion and the wishes of the parents. When the parents are in disagreement, other than in British Columbia, the father, except in special circumstances, has the right to direct and regulate the religious education of his child. This right of the father is recognized even where the child is illegitimate, except in Ontario; but, when the mother is the sole support of the child, her wishes are given some prominence. Further, the father's wishes concerning the religious education of his child are recognized after his death; and, if he die without having left any direction as to the religion in which his child is to be educated, it is presumed that he intended the religious training to be in his own faith. In brief, when there is disagreement, the Department respects the wishes of the father, unless there is some strong reason for disregarding them. Of course, some consideration is given to the wishes of a widowed mother - in British Columbia her wishes are the deciding factor - and, in the case of an adopted child, to the wishes of the foster father. A guardian, appointed by the father, is given equal rights with the widowed mother in this connection. Another deciding factor, particularly in the event of a foster home, is the best interests of the child itself.

In practice, if there is any doubt concerning the school a child should attend, the Department endeavours to ascertain the religion of the parents and the real wish of the father. We look for evidence concerning the bona fide nature of his wish, if he requests that his child be given an education under the auspices of a church to which he does not adhere. Because of subsequent difficulties, the Department is extremely reluctant to admit to a Protestant school a child of Roman Catholic parents, and similarly, a child of Protestant parents to a Roman Catholic school. In extraordinary cases, when departure from the usual practice is being considered, we not only ask for an affidavit from the father, but we insist upon a few months' consideration. Then keeping in mind the best interests of the child, a decision is given, and the child must then attend the school selected.
The practice of transferring a child from one residential school to another for religious reasons would lead to endless applications for a change and would result in considerable difficulty. Further, a pupil that has been resident in a school may have formed religious opinions and even convictions, and a disturbance of these might be untimely.

In view of the fact that this girl was a pupil at the Ermineskin School for approximately seven years, the Department feels that it would be in her best interests to remain in that institution. You will note particularly, the following statements made in this letter -

"The practice of transferring a child from one residential school to another for religious reasons would lead to endless applications for a change and would result in considerable difficulty. Further, a pupil that has been resident in a school may have formed religious opinions and even convictions, and a disturbance of these might be untimely."

Reverend E.J. Staley, Principal of the Edmonton Residential School had no right at all to accept this girl as a pupil. Indian Agents and Principals have been repeatedly advised when there is any doubt whatsoever regarding the eligibility of a pupil to a residential school, either on account of religious or other reasons, such child should not be placed in any residential school until all the facts have been laid before the Department and our decision has been given. Reverend Mr. Staley apparently ignored our instructions in this regard.

Our decision, therefore, is that Betsy Lightning should be returned to the Ermineskin School and you should make the necessary arrangements for this transfer immediately. If you so desire, you can show this letter to the Reverend Principal of the Edmonton School.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Robertson:

I am enclosing herewith Voucher in the amount of $189.84, covering amounts paid out to Railroad and Transportation Companies for the transportation charges in connection with the return of the children of this school to their homes on the different reserves.

I am sending you the voucher in the hope that the Department will pay it.

I would explain that if the school were located on a reserve, there would be no problem of transportation involved, but, having to recruit our children from all over Central Alberta as we do, transportation becomes a real problem and I cannot see why the school should be called upon to meet the extra expense.

I am not sending you a voucher covering the amounts paid out for bringing the children in, until I see whether or not the Department gives favorable consideration to my request for payment of the outgoing expenses, but I consider that that too is a legitimate charge against the Department.

Don't you think it might be well to put something in the estimates this year to cover these expenses?

Yours very truly,

J.T. Staley,
Asst. Principal.

Mr. E.A. Robertson, Indian Agent,

We have your letter of the 10th instant enclosing voucher for transportation of children from the Edmonton Residential School. You should point out to the principal that authority should have been requested for this expenditure before submitting a voucher.

In connection with the transportation of children to their homes, it is expected that the principal of the school will make every effort to have the parents come for their children and also return them. In the majority of schools the parents supply the funds for the transportation of their children in the event that they do not come to the school for them. The individual items of expenditure appear small and there should have been no difficulty in obtaining same from the parents concerned.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

In reply to your 110-0-10 (WT 1) dated October 29th regarding the admission of Percy Williams to the Edmonton Indian Residential School. I beg to advise you that the only other child of Cecilia Lightning at the Edmonton Residential School is John Lightning. She states that it is her intention to place all of her children in the same school.

Percy Williams is the son of Cecilia Lightning and Willie Williams (deceased). They were married in the R.C. Church and the father was a Roman Catholic. This boy has been brought up by his grandfather, Frank Yellowbird, and although the boy is over 10 years of age, the grandfather could not be induced to place him in school. Percy gave some trouble to the police last summer, breaking into cottages at Ma-Me-O Beach and the grandfather was informed that he must be placed in school this fall. For this reason, when the grandfather and mother agreed to send him to the Edmonton Residential School, I did not hesitate to recommend his admission, and allowed him to proceed to school, rather than see him get into further trouble.

H.N. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.

This child was admitted to the Ermineskin Indian Residential School on October 21st, 1944. Last year they placed their two sons, Colin and Robert, in the Edmonton School and Mr. Moore, who was Clerk-in-Charge at that time, not knowing they had another child in the Ermineskin School, forwarded their application, which was approved by the Department.

Father Adam announced that he was very well pleased with the way the pupils had returned from the Fall and Christmas Holidays and he planned to grant another 2 days' holiday. The dates agreed upon was from Friday evening Feb. 27th until Sunday evening Feb. 29th. The children to be ready to commence work on Monday morning March 1st. The R.C. School Trustees (Dan Buffalo & Dan Johnson) agreed to make the dates known to the parents and to ask them to see that the children returned to school promptly.

Father Adam then asked for anyone who was interested in tanning elk hides to see him. He had a number to be tanned and offered to pay $5.00 and to give one elk hide to anyone who would tan two hides for him.

The Supt. also stated that the Camsell Hospital would also like to get some hides, already tanned if possible. He would give them further information as to the price of same, etc., when he had seen Dr. Stone. He also brought up the subject of parents taking pupils from one school and putting them into another. The Department strongly objected to changing pupils from one school to another, and would not authorize such changes. This was brought up especially in the case of Bertha Sittingweasel and Rita Roasting who had been taken from the Ermineskin School and sent to the Edmonton School.

Rev. Father Alan and Rev. Mr. Law each presented their side of the history of these cases, and it was left to the Council to ask any questions or make any recommendations they might see fit. Chief James Crane also gave further information regarding Bertha Sittingweasel. He stated that the mother and stepfather were originally Catholics, and that as far as Bertha was concerned, she should remain a Catholic until she was old enough to make her own choice. Philip Soosay stated that the parents should have the authority to decide which school their children attend. Fred Littlepoplar stated that in his opinion, the parents should be able to decide as to what school their children should go, and he hoped that such questions as these, arising from differences of religion could be settled on a friendly basis, without argument on either side.

The Supt. then explained the Indian Act concerning the attendance of school children, and also the Department's instructions in this connection. He also explained the problem of getting non-treaty half-breeds who are living on the Reserves, into the Hobema Day School, as the rate payers had objected to any more half-breeds going to their school. A meeting had been held at the school which was attended by himself and some of the staff, where the rate payers had presented a resolution regarding the education of these halfbreeds. (Copy of this resolution attached).

Johnny Crier then asked that when school children used gum, balloons and other things that they put into their mouths, they should be instructed not to pass such things on to other children, from one mouth to another. Father Adam stated that this practice was forbidden at the school, but that it was hard to enforce this rule at times. Rev. Father Adam and Rev. Mr. Law then left the meeting (4.15).

(signed)
H N Woodsworth
Superintendent

Louis Lightning made application to have his girl Betsy returned from the Edmonton School to look after her mother who is expecting a child soon. Superintendent gave him a letter asking the Principal if he could release her for a few days, as the admission of this girl to the Edmonton School had not been approved by the Department.

Superintendent told Council that Mr. Gooderham had stated that both of the Residential schools were filled to capacity. In September a certain number would be discharged, and would create a few vacancies, and any children whose applications had been approved would be the first to be admitted to school. No new children would be admitted to school after the first of the school year, and any truants not attending would be taken immediately to school without hesitation. No children are wanted in school over 12 years of age. The Chief then presented a resolution from his band asking that another school be built immediately on the Samson's reserve, either a non-sectarian residential school where the children would be allowed to go home very Friday evening, or a consolidated day school, where the children could be transported to school each morning and returned in the evening, to their homes.

H N Woodsworth
Superintendent

DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES
INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH

March 19th, 1948

Chief Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Percy Williams

With reference to your 110-0-10 (WT 1) dated December 23rd, 1947, Percy Williams.

It has been the endeavour of this office to follow as closely as possible the law as outlined in subsection 2 of section 10 of the Indian Act.

The parents propose to apply for admission to the Edmonton Indian Residential School for Archie Lightning, to follow up on what seems to be their determination to send their children to the Edmonton School. The boy is doing very well at school, and the R.C.M.P. have been well satisfied that the trouble in cottage breaking-in has been eliminated at Pigeon Lake.

I recommend that the parents be allowed to follow their desire in sending all their children to Edmonton, and not some to one school and some to another. There seems to be no religious conviction one way or the other on their part. Percy Williams (Lightning) should therefore be eligible as a grant earning pupil at the Edmonton School, as well as his brother John.

H.N. Woodsworth,
Superintendent.

Re: School Children - Wabamum Reserve,
Edmonton Indian Agency.

On my recent trip into the north, Mr. Robertson stated that there were thirteen children of school age of the Roman Catholic faith on the Wabamum Reserve for whom there is no residential school of their faith available. The Principal of the Edmonton Residential School (United Church) had stated that he would be glad to take them into residence, if there was no objection. As you are aware, the majority of the people on this Reserve are Protestant, and a day school should be started, even in a temporary building, as soon as possible.
